data.quote: ἄλγημα . . ἐς γλουτὸν ἢ ὀσφὺν ὀκέλλει

definition: ὅκκα, Dor. Adv., = ὅκα, ὅτε, Alcm. 94, Cerc. 7.11, Epigr. in Berl.Sitzb. 1894.908. (From *ὁδ-κᾰ, cf. Lesb. ὄττι from *ὅδ-τι, etc.)

children.definition: Dor. for ὅταν, Epich. 165, al., Sophr. 46, Ar. Ach. 762 (Megar.), IG 5(1).962.26 ( Lacon.), 12(1).694.17 ( Rhodes, iii B. C.), Archyt. Fr. 1, Theoc. 1.87, 4.21. [ ὅκκᾱ Epich. 165, Theoc. 8.68, 11.22 ( ὅκκʼ Ar. l.c., ὅκχʼ Epich. 29, etc., v. κᾱ) : ὅκκᾰ Theoc. 4.21, AP 6.353.4, by confusion with foreg.]
bracelet, armlet, EM 383.21, Hsch.

definition: ὄκκον ὀφθαλμόν, Hsch. :—hence ὄκταλλος ( Boeot.), ὁ,

children.definition: eye, Hdn.Gr. 2.559, restored in Corinn. Supp. 2.89.—Cf. ὄπτιλλος. (Derived by various suffixes from root oqṷ- ‘see’ in ὄψομαι, ὄσσε, ὄσσομαι, ὀφθαλμός, Lat. oculus.) ὀκκῦλαι· τὸ ὀκλάσαι, καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν πτερ<ν>ῶν καθέζεσθαι, Hsch.

definition: ὀκλαδία, ἡ, ( ὀκλάζω)= ὄκλασις, Suid., perh. to be read in Cael. Aur. TP 5.133.

children.definition: folding-chair, camp-stool, IG 1(2).282.119, Ar. Eq. 1384, 1386, Luc. Lex. 6 ; δίφρος ὀ. Paus. 1.27.1, Heraclid. Pont. ap. Ath. 12.512c.

definition: ὀκλαδιστί, Adv., = sq., ὀ. πηδᾶν, of a frog

children.definition: hopping, Babr. 25.7 (written ὄκλαστι in Suid.) :—also ὄκλᾰδ-ις, Hdn.Gr. 1.512.
with bent hams, in crouching, cowering posture, A.R. 3.122, Nonn. D. 1.358, al.; cf. ὀκλάξ.

definition: ὀκλάζω, fut. -άσω Ph. (v. infr. 2) : aor. ὤκλασα S. OC 196 (lyr.), Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.320d :— Med., Ep. aor. opt. ὀκλάσσαιντο Euph. 17 :—

children.definition: crouch down with bent hams, squat (in Hom. only μετοκλάζω), of a Persian dance, ὤκλαζε καὶ ἐξανίστατο X. An. 6.1.10 (cf. ὄκλασμα) ; διπλοῦς ὀκλάζων S. Ichn. 90 ; ἐς γόνυ ὀκλάσας δέχεται τῇ σαρίσσῃ τὴν ἐπέλασιν, of a soldier waiting an attack, Luc. DMort. 22[27].4, cf. Philops. 18 ; sink down, of a weary traveller, S. l.c. ; of oxen, Mosch. 2.99 ; of horses that crouch down to let their rider mount, Plu. Coniug. 2.139b (but of horses that stumble and throw their rider, Procop. Vand. 2.21, al.) ; of the wolf crouching down to let the Twins suck, Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.320d ; θρόνος . . ὀκλάζων folding-seat, D.Chr. 1.78 : c. acc., ὀ. τὰ ὀπίσθια, τοὺς προσθίους, bend their hind- or fore-legs, X. Eq. 11.3, Ael. NA 7.4 :— Med., Euph. l.c.

sink, slacken, abate, ἀπειρίᾳ σοφιστικῶν παλαισμάτων ὀκλάσομεν Ph. 1.199 ; τόνος ὀκλάζων Gal. 11.172 ; ποδῶν δέ οἱ ὤκλασεν ὁρμή Musae. 325 ; of the wind, τῆς φορᾶς Hld. 5.23, cf. Adam. Vent. 37 ; ὤκλαζε αὐτοῖς ὁ θυμός ib. 7 ; κραδίης ὤκλασεν ὄγκος AP 5.250 ( Iren.).

children.label: II
children.definition: abate, ὀκλάσας τὸν πόθον Hld. 1.26.
Hp. Haem. 4 ; ὀ. καθῆσθαι squat down, Pherecr. 75, cf. A.R. 3.1308, Arat. 517 (f.l. for ὀκλάς), Sor. 1.61, Gal. UP 3.15, Luc. Lex. 11.
the bent hams, Arat. 517 (as read by Hipparchus).
crouching with bent hams, squatting, Hp. Art. 82, Luc. Salt. 41.
squatted from time to time, Ar. Fr. 344b.

definition: ὀκνάδραστον πᾶν πρᾶγμα ἄγνωμον, Hsch. ( οἰκν- cod., sed post ὀκνείω).

children.definition: ὀκνηρός, Nonn. D. 18.207. Adv. -έως Musae. 120.

definition: ὀκνέω, Ep. ὀκνείω Il. 5.255 : impf. ὤκνεον 20.155 : fut. -ήσω Isoc. 6.72 : aor. ὤκνησα D. 18.103, etc. : ( ὄκνος) :—

children.definition: shrink from doing, scruple, hesitate to do a thing, c. inf., ὀκνείω ἵππων ἐπιβαινέμεν Il. 5.255 ; ἀρχέμεναι πολέμοιο ὤκνεον 20.155.—In Att. mostly with collat. sense of the feeling which causes the hesitation, and so,

ὀκνῶ προδότης καλεῖσθαι I shrink from being called, fear to be called, S. Ph. 93, cf. Th. 5.61, Lys. Fr. 23 ; οἷα ἐγὼ ὀκνῶ πρὸς ὑμᾶς ὀνομάσαι shrink from naming, hesitate to name, D. 2.19, cf. Pl. Grg. 462e ; τοσαῦθʼ ὅσʼ ὀκνήσαιμʼ ἂν . . εἰπεῖν D. 18.103, cf. 24.7, etc.
σὰς ὀκνῶ θρᾶξαι φρένας A. Pr. 628, cf. S. El. 1271.

μεμηνότʼ ἄνδρα . . ὀκνεῖς ἰδεῖν Id. Aj. 81, cf. Th. 1.120, etc.—The Homeric constr. c. inf. continued most common (v. supr.): rarely c. acc., πῶς τὸ μητρὸς λέκτρον οὐκ ὀκνεῖν με δεῖ; S. OT 976 ; ὃν μήτʼ ὀκνεῖτε Id. OC 731, cf. X. Cyr. 2.2.21 ; ἂν ὀκνῇς τὸ μανθάνειν Philem. 213.1 ; also ὀ. περί τινος X. Cyr. 4.5.20 ; ὀ. μή . . Pl. Phdr. 257c, X. An. 2.3.9, D. 1.18.

children.label: II
children.definition: shrink, hesitate, hang back, Hdt. 7.50, S. El. 22, 320, Antipho Soph. 55, Luc. Prom. 18, etc. ; of soldiers, Arist. Pol. 1297b11.
fill with reluctance, Al. Nu. 32.9.
LXX Ec. 10.18, PMasp. 158.15 (vi A. D.), Gloss.

shrinking, timid, ἐλπίδες -ότεραι Pi. N. 11.22 ; ἀσθενέας καὶ ὀ. Hp. Acut. 28 ; -ότερος ἐς τὴν πρᾶξιν Antipho 2.3.5 ; ἐς τὰ πολεμικὰ -ότεροι Th. 4.55, cf. 1.142 ; esp. from fear, opp. τολμηρός, D. 25.24 ; τὸ θῆλυ -ότερον Arist. HA 608b13. Adv. -ρῶς reluctantly, X. An. 7.1.7 ; ὀ. διακεῖσθαι D. 10.28 : Comp. -ότερον X. Cyr. 1.4.6.
idle, sluggish, Hierocl. Facet. 211, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: causing fear, vexatious, troublesome, ἡμῖν μὲν . . ταῦτʼ ὀκνηρά S. OT 834.
reluctance, Procop. Vand. 1.22, al.
one must shrink, hesitate, Pl. Lg. 891d, Arist. SE 175b38, etc.

shrinking, hesitation, οὔτε τί με δέος ἴσχει ἀκήριον οὔτε τις ὄ. Il. 5.817 (answering to κάματος in 811), cf. 13.224 ; οὔτʼ ὄκνῳ εἴκων οὔτʼ ἀφραδίῃσι νόοιο 10.122, cf. A. Th. 54, S. Ant. 243 ; ὄ. τις καὶ μέλλησις Th. 7.49 ; ἀμαθία μὲν θράσος, λογισμὸς δὲ ὄ. φέρει Id. 2.40, etc. ; τὸν μὲν ὄ. ψόγον, τὸν δὲ πόνον ἔπαινον ἡγουμένη Isoc. 1.7 : hence,

data.quote: οὔτε τί με δέος ἴσχει ἀκήριον οὔτε τις ὄ.
οὔτʼ ὄκνῳ εἴκων οὔτʼ ἀφραδίῃσι νόοιο
ἀμαθία μὲν θράσος, λογισμὸς δὲ ὄ. φέρει
τὸν μὲν ὄ. ψόγον, τὸν δὲ πόνον ἔπαινον ἡγουμένη

children.definition: alarm, fear, A. Ag. 1009 (lyr.), S. Ph. 225 : c. gen., τοῦ μάλιστʼ ὄ. σʼ ἔχει Id. OC 652 : in pl., ἀναβολαὶ καὶ ὄκνοι Pl. Lg. 768e, cf. D. 18.246 :— Constr. : c. gen., τοῦ πόνου γὰρ οὐκ ὄ. [ἐστί] I grudge not labour, S. Ph. 887, cf. OC l.c. : c. inf., παρέσχεν ὄ. μὴ ἐλθεῖν made them hesitate to . . , Th. 3.39 ; ὄ. ἦν ἀνίστασθαι X. An. 4.4.11 ; ὄ. πρός τι Pl. Lg. 665d.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ὄκνος personified, as title of picture by Polygnotus, Paus. 10.29.2, Plin. HN 35.137, cf. D.S. 1.97.

children.label: III
children.definition: ὄ. χαλκοῦς, a seat used by women in Bithynia, Suid.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Arist. HA 617a5, Ael. NA 5.36, Ant.Lib. 7.6.
Dionys. Av. 1.6.

definition: ὁκοδαπός, ὁκόθεν, ὁκοῖος, ὁκόσος, ὁκότε, ὁκότερος, ὅκου, Ion. for ὁποδαπός, etc.

children.definition: πάρνοψ, Hsch., Phot., cf. A. Fr. 256.
to be rough or angry, S. Fr. 1075.
to be made rough or jagged : metaph., πανθυμαδὸν ὀκριόωντο they grew furiously angry with each other, Od. 18.33 ; ὠκριωμένος enraged, Lyc. 545.
platform or tribune in the Odeum at Athens, on which the actors appeared at the Proagon, Pl. Smp. 194b ; but expld. as τὸ λογεῖον ἐφʼ οὗ οἱ τραγῳδοὶ ἠγωνίζοντο, Hsch.
Philostr. VA 6.11, VS 1.9.1 : in pl., Id. VA 5.9, Them. Or. 26.316d, Luc. Ner. 9.
painterʼs easel, Poll. 7.129.
raised seat of the chariot-driver, Hsch., Phot., Suid.
ὑπερθέντων ὀκρ[ίβαντα] IG 12(8).261 ( Thasos).

children.label: III
children.definition: ass or wild goat, Anon. ap. Hsch.

definition: ὀκρίβατον σχῆμα ἡνιόχου, Hsch. (i. e. ὀκρίβας· ὄχημα ἡνιόχου, v. foreg.).

children.definition: rugged, jagged, Hp. Art. 36 ( Comp.), Aret. SD 2.13.

having many points or roughnesses, rugged, jagged, of unhewn stone, χερμάδιον, λίθος, μάρμαρος, Il. 4.518, 8.327, 12.380, 16.735 ; χερμάς A. Th. 300 (lyr.) ; χθών Id. Pr. 283 (anap.) ; οὔρεα Nic. Th. 470 ; also βέλος ὀ. Theoc. 25.231 : metaph., of a Satyrʼs head, Nonn. D. 14.137. (v. ὀκρυόεις sub fin.)
jagged point or prominence, any roughness on an edge or surface, as of a fractured bone, Hp. Art. 14.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. ὀκρίς, ίδος, ὁ, ἡ, = ὀκριόεις, rugged, φάραγξ A. Pr. 1016. (Cf. Umbr. ocar (acc. ocrem, etc.) ‘arx, mons’, OLat. ocris = mons confragosus.)

chilling, horrible, πολέμου . . ἐπιδημίου ὀκρυόεντος Il. 9.64 ; ἐμεῖο κυνὸς κακομηχάνου ὀκρυοέσσης (Helen loq.) 6.344 ; ὀ. φόβος A.R. 2.607 ; ὀ. βᾶρις, of Charon’s boat, AP 7.67 ( Leon.) ; ἀταρπιτὸς ὀ. Parm. (?) 20 ; ὀκρυόειν ἔδαφος Eleg.Alex.Adesp. 1.7. (Freq. confused with ὀκρυόεις : ὀκρυόεις may have arisen from an early mistake in the division of words in Hom. (leg. ἐπιδημίοο κρυόεντος, κακομηχάνοο κ.) ; or ὀκ. may be cogn. with Skt. άσρυ, Lith. ašara ‘tear’, and the Adj. would then mean tearful.)
consisting of eight pieces, ἄρτον τετράτρυφον ὀκτάβλωμον, an obscure conjunction of epithets, Hes. Op. 442, cf. Philostr. Im. 2.26.
consisting of eight letters, PMag. Par. 1.783.
octagonal, Sch. Papp. ap. Archim. 2p.541H.
eight-cornered, Gem. 2.15, Nicom. Ar. 2.11, Alex.Trall. 8.2 :
octagon, Antipho Soph. 13.
= sq., ξύλον Heliod. ap. Orib. 49.4.71, cf. 49.23.4.
eight fingers long or broad, Clearch. 73, PCair.Zen. 483 (iii B. C.) :— older Att. ὀκτωδάκτῠλος Ar. Lys. 109, Supp.Epigr. 3.137 iii 11 (iv B. C.), IG 2(2).1627.123, and so in Ion., Hp. Steril. 221.
bird-cage, Hsch.
worth eight drachmae, Epigr. ap. Dioph. 5.30.
privileged to pay only eight drachmae as poll-tax, Sammelb. 7440.6,32 (ii A. D.).
of an octahedron, Olymp. in Phd. p.238N.

definition: ὀκτάεδρος, ον, of a solid figure,

children.definition: eight-sided, Gal. 5.668 : Subst. ὀκτά-εδρον, τό, octahedron, Arist. Cael. 307a16, Ti.Locr. 98d, Euc. 11 Def. 26, Placit. 2.6.5.
containing eight ingredients, φάρμακον v.l. in Paul.Aeg. 3.78.

cycle of eight years, used at Athens before Metonʼs time for bringing the lunar and solar years together, 3 months being intercalated to complete the sum of 2,922 days, Eudox. Ars 13.12, Str. 7.5.5, Gem. 8.27 sqq., Placit. 2.32.2.
eight years old, Hp. Epid. 1.10 ; of eight years, χρόνος D.S. 17.94 :—fem. ὀκτα-έτις, ἡ, IG 4.620, Pl. Ep. 361d.
Theo Sm. p.173 H., Procl. Par.Ptol. 285 ; but ὀκτωετία in Ptol. Tetr. 205.
eight days old, Ep.Phil. 3.5.
twenty-eight years old, App.Anth. 2.246 ( Citium).
Dor. for ὀκτακόσιοι, IG 5(1).1 A 16 ( Sparta) ; ηοκτακ. Tab.Heracl. 2.79.
with eight spokes, EM 621.16.
eight times, Luc. Ind. 4, etc. :—also ὀκτάκι, Epigr.Gr. 356.4 ( Hadriani), Iamb. in Nic. pp. 17,90 P. ; ὀκτάκιν, IG 5(1).213.19,25 ( Sparta).
eighty thousand, D.S. 14.47, Luc. VH 1.13.

definition: ὀκτακισχίλιοι [ῑ], αι, α, Dor. ὀκτᾰκισχήλιοι Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).25 ( Cyrene) :—

children.definition: eight thousand, Hdt. 9.28, X. An. 5.5.4, etc. : also in sg., ἵππος ὀκτακισχιλίη, for ὀκτακισχίλιοι ἱππεῖς, ʼ8,000 horse’, Hdt. 7.85 ; so ὀ. ἀσπίς Id. 5.30.
eight-thousandth, Theo Sm. p.125 H.
dining-room of eight couches, Arist. Mir. 830a16.
eight-spoked, κύκλα Il. 5.723.
eight hundred, Hdt. 2.9, Th. 1.55, etc.
eight-hundredth, ἔτος D.C. 60.29.
holding eight cotylae, ψυκτήρ Ath. 5.180a.
of eight lines, στροφή Sch. Ar. Ach. 565, Heph. Poëm. 4.
possessing eight lobes, πνεύμων Ar.Byz. Epit. 77.14.
force of eight λόχοι, Ascl. Tact. 2.9.
of or in eight parts, D.L. 7.110.
of eight measures : -μετρον, τό, octameter, Sch.Heph. p.132 C.
of eight months, ἀνοχαί D.S. 14.38 ; χρόνος POxy. 1627.9 (iv A.D.) ; eight months old, Ar.Byz. Epit. 77.18.

eight months old, in the eighth month, Hp. Alim. 42, X. Cyn. 7.6, Arist. HA 545a29, etc. ; of eight months’ duration, IG 11(2).199 A 13 ( Delos, iii B. C.) ; ὀκτάμηνος as fem., X. l.c., Hp. Epid. 2.3.17 ; (sc. περίοδος) PCair.Zen. 327.77 (iii B. C.) ; but ὀκτάμηναι Arist. HA 583b33.
containing eight sextarii, POxy. 1896.19 (vi A.D.).
= Lat. bes, Gloss.
eight palms wide or long, ἀσπίς Ael. Tact. 12 : so ὀκτωπάλαιστος, Ascl. Tact. 5.1.

definition: ὀκτάπεδος, ον, Dor. for ὀκτάπους, Tab.Heracl. 2.45, al. (in form ηοκτ-).

children.definition: eight cubits long, δοκός Inscr.Délos 290.174 (iii B. C.), Callix. 2, cf. LXX 3 Ki. 7.47(10), Plb. 5.89.6, Str. 3.5.5.
multiply by eight, Gem. 8.38.47 ( Pass.).
eightfold, Ar. Eq. 70, Pl. Ti. 35c.
eight plethra long or large, D.H. 4.61.
eightfold, SIG 672.18 ( Delph., ii B. C.) : fem. -πλῆ Gal. 13.717.
eight feet long, Hes. Op. 425.

children.label: II
children.definition: eight-footed, καρκίνος Nic. Th. 605.

definition: ὀκτάπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: eight-footed, καρκίνοι Batr. 298 ; πάγουρος AP 6.196 ( Stat.Flacc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., ὀκτάπους, ὁ, Octopus vulgaris, Alex.Trall. 7.1.
Luc. Scyth. 1.
with eight spokes, EM 621.16.
tenant of eight ἄρουραι, PFlor. 18.12 (ii A. D.).
with eight roots, ὀκτάρριζα μετώπων φράγματα, of a stagʼshorns, with eight points, AP 6.110 ( Leon. or Mnasalc.).
with eight poles, or rather, so constructed as to be drawn by eight pairs of horses or oxen, X. Cyr. 6.1.52.
the number eight, Arist. Metaph. 1082a30.

children.label: II
children.definition: body of eight men, Nic.Dam. 60 J.
of eight times, Sch. A. Th. 103. Adv. -μως in the eight-time measure, of the dochmius ( ⏑_ _⏑_ ), Sch. A. Th. 128.
eight-legged, ἐπίδεσμος Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.21.1, cf. Gal. 18(1).774.
containing eight σοῦφα (Egypt. measure of capacity), Sammelb. 1958 (iii A. D.).
eightfold, POxy. 1638.30 (iii A. D.).
eight stadia long, Plb. 34.12.4.
with eight columns in front, of temples, Vitr. 3.2.7.
system of eight spheres, Phlp. in Ph. 599.10, al. : as neut., Simp. in Cael. 435.4.
containing the first eight books of the Old Testament, Phot. Bibl. pp. 7,128 B. : title of work by Ostanes, Ph.Bybl. ap. Eus. PE 1.10.
divided into eight tomes, βίβλος Alex.Trall. 7.9.
eight-stretched, ἕλικες ὀ. the eight arms of the octopus, AP 9.14 ( Antiphil.).
the first eight τόποι of the δωδεκάτροπος, Vett.Val. 334.20.
with eight wheels, Ath.Mech. 18.16.
Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(3).117.21 (nisi leg. ὀκτάτροπος) ; cf. octotropos, [Manil.] 2.969.
octaphorus, v. ὀκτώφορος.
with eight strings or notes, ἐμμέλεια Plu. An.procr. 2.1029c ; συστήματα Aristox. Harm. p.96 M., Theo Sm. p.49 H. : -χορδον, τό, octachord, Nicom. Harm. 11, POxy. 667.24.
composed of eight time-units, Procl. in Prm. p.990S.
in eight ways, EM 461.15, Simp. in Cat. 436.19.
warship with eight rowers to each oar, Plb. 16.3.2, Plu. Ant. 61.

definition: ὀκτώ, Boeot. ὀκτό IG 7.3193.6,9 (iii B. C.), Heraclean hοκτώ Tab.Heracl. 1.34, Elean ὀπτώ Schwyzer 419.4 (v/iv B. C.) : οἱ, αἱ, τά :— indecl.,

children.definition: eight, Il. 2.313, etc. : prov. πάντα ὀ., in reference to the eight spheres, Timoth. ap. Theo Sm. p.105 H. (Cf. Skt. aṣṭấ, aṣṭáu, Lat. octo, Goth. ahtau, etc.)
a work in eight volumes, Gal. 7.311.
eight obols, IG 5(1).1433 ( Messene) ; also ἁ ὀκτώβολος εἰσφορά tax of eight obols per mina, ib. 1432.3 (i A. D.).
eighteen, Hdt. 2.111, etc.
at the price of eighteen drachmae, πωλεῖν τὰς κριθὰς -μους D. 42.20.
period of eighteen years, Ptol. Alm. 4.3, al.

definition: ὀκτωκαιδεκαέτης, ες, later form of ὀκτωκαιδεκέτης, Luc. DMort. 22[27].7, etc. :—fem. ὀκτωκαιδεκα-έτις, ιδος, Id. Tox. 24, DMeretr. 8.2.

children.definition: eighteen times, Theol.Ar. 64 :—also ὀκτωκαιδέκα-κι, Ptol. Alm. 9.3.
eighteen feet long, ξύλα IG 42(1).109 ii 138 ( Epid., iii B. C.).
eighteen cubits long, ξύλον IG 11 (2).203 B 100 ( Delos, iii B. C.) ; δοκοί D.S. 17.105.
eighteen-fold, Aristarch.Sam. 7, Placit. 2.31.2, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.925c, Procl. Hyp. 4.107 :—also ὀκτωκαιδεκα-πλᾰσίων, ον, gen. ονος, Archim. Aren. 1.9.
the number eighteen, Theol.Ar. 39.
of eighteen times, in Prosody, Aristid. Quint. 1.14, Anon. in Musici Scriptores p.414 von Jan.
on the eighteenth day, Hp. Morb. 2.25.
eighteenth, -δεκάτη (sc. ἡμέρᾳ) on the eighteenth day, Od. 5.279, 24.65 ; ἔτος Plb. 1.56.2, etc. ; Boeot. ὀκτοκηδέκατος Schwyzer 485.39 ( Thespiae, iii B. C.).

definition: ὀκτωκαιδεκέτης, ες (also ὀκτωκαι-δεχέτης Supp.Epigr. 4.190 ( Halic., iv B. C.)),

children.definition: eighteen years old, D. 40.4, Theoc. 15.129 :—fem. ὀκτωκαιδεκᾰτ-έτις, ιδος, AP 7.167.
twenty-eight-fold, Placit. 2.20.1.
of twenty-eight notes, Nicom. Exc. 6.
twenty-eighth, Archim. Aren. 4.6, al.
consisting of thirty-eight μέτρα, Sch. Ar. Pax 153.
solid figure with thirty-eight faces, Papp. ap. Archim. 2p.537H.
EM 767.34 :—also ὀκτω-μηνιαῖος, α, ον, Ph. 1.29, Sch. Arat. 455 ; born in the eighth month, βρέφη Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.47.
Philem. 212.
Subst., = σκορπίος, -πουν ἀνεγείρεις Cratin. 77 : acc. pl. [ὀκ]τώπους (dub. sens.) prob. in PCair.Zen. 510 (iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: eight feet long, IG 1(2).313.90 ; of eight square feet, χωρίον Pl. Men. 82e, 83a.
borne by eight, octophorus lectica or octophorus alone, a litter carried by eight, Cic. Verr. 5.11.27, QF 2.8.2 ; octǎphorus, Mart. 6.84.

definition: ὄκωχα, old pf. of ἔχω, whence perh. συν-οχωκότε (q.v.) Il. 2.218 :— hence ὀκωχ-εύω,

children.definition: hold, S. Fr. 327 ( κωχεύουσι cod. Hsch. who also has ὀκωχεύειν· ἔχειν, συνέχειν) :
hold, stay, EM 596.50 :
bound, under obligation, Riv.Fil. 56.263 ( Cyrene).

definition: ὄλα τὰ ἐντὸς τῆς σηπίας στρογγύλα, Hsch. ; cf. ὀλός.
ὀλαεῖ ἐνοχλεῖ, καὶ ὀλαθεῖ ὁμοίως, Hsch.
ὀλαιμεύς ὁ ( τὸ cod.) τὰς ὀλὰς βάλλων, Hsch. ὀλαιτοί· σπερμολόγοι, καὶ ὀλατοί, Id., cf. Orus ap. EM 622.9, Phot. ϝόλαμος (written γόλ-) · διωγμός, Hsch. (cf. οὐλαμός).

children.definition: of solid silver, Ptol.Euerg. 9 J., Callix. 2 ; νόμισμα Ph. 2.276.

definition: ὁλάω, lisping pronunciation of ὁράω, Ar. V. 45.
ὀλβάχιον, τό, Dinol. 13 :—also ὀλβάχνιον, ὄλεχον, EM 257.53, 621.20 ; ὀλβακήϊα, Hsch. :—said to be Syracusan for ὀλάχνιον, and expld. as τὸ κανοῦν ἐν ᾧ ἀπετίθεντο τὰς οὐλάς. ( β

children.definition: bliss, Phot.

definition: Ὄλβια, τά, older form for Ἄλπια,

children.definition: the Alps, Posidon. 48 J. ; Ὄλπια in EM 623.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ὀλβία, ἡ, name of several cities, of which the best known was the Milesian colony in Scythia, SIG 286.15 (iv B. C.), Str. 7.3.17, etc. : its citizens being Ὀλβιοπολῖται, Hdt. 4.18, SIG 286.1 : hence Adj. Ὀλβιοπολῑτικός, ή, όν, ib. 218.16.

definition: ὀλβίζω, fut. -ιῶ E. Hel. 228 : aor. ὤλβισα S. Fr. 646.1, etc. :— Pass. (v. infr.) :— make happy, E. Ph. 1689, Hel. l.c.(lyr.);

children.definition: deem or pronounce happy, A. Ag. 928, S. OT 1529, etc. :— Pass., to be or be deemed happy, τίς δʼ οἶκος . . ὠλβίσθη ποτέ ; Id. Fr. 942 ; οἱ τὰ πρῶτʼ ὠλβισμένοι E. IA 51 ; μέγα ὀλβισθείς Id. Tr. 1253 (anap.).
giving a prosperous life, epith. of Heracles, Fouilles de lʼInst. Français dʼarch. Orientale 4(2).72 ( Egypt).
whose happiness is in his belly, a belly-god, Amphis 10.
of blessed lot, Il. 3.182.
bestowing bliss, χθών (as v.l. for βιόδωρος) E. Hipp. 749 (lyr.) ; μέθυ AP 11.60.9 ( Paul.Sil.).
bestower of bliss, Orph. H. 34.2 :—fem. ὀλβιο-δῶτις, ιδος, ib. 40.2, etc.
making happy, epith. of Dionysus, AP 9.525.16.
heart-gladdening, ζωή Orph. H. 19.21.
Orph. H. 26.6.
blest in wealth, Philox. 3.22.

definition: ὄλβιος, ον Tz. H. 1.600, but usu. α, ον, as Pi. O. 13.4, E. Alc. 452 (lyr.), Or. 1338 : ( ὄλβος) :

children.label: I
children.definition: happy, blest, esp. with reference to worldly goods, οἶκον . . ἔναιον ὄλβιος ἀφνειόν Od. 17.420, cf. Il. 24.543 (nowhere else in Il.), etc. ; εὐδαίμων τε καὶ ὄ. Hes. Op. 826 ; χρήμασι ὄ. Hdt. 8.75 ; μέγα ὄλβιος Id. 6.24 ; Πριάμου τοῦ μέγʼ ὀλβίου E. Hec. 493 ; τοῖς ὀλβίοις A. Ag. 941 ; ὄ. δῶμα Pi. N. 9.3 ; τὰν ὀλβίαν Κόρινθον Id. O. 13.4 ; also of more than mere outward prosperity, Hdt. 1.30- 2.

happy, blessed, ὄλβιον ξάνθαν ἐλάτηρα πώλων Alc. Supp. 8.14 ; ὄλβιε Ζεῦ A. Supp. 526 (lyr.) ; Διὶ ὀ. εὐχαριστήριον CIG 2017 (Thrac. Chers.), cf. JHS 25.56 (Cyzic.); ὄ. ὅστις ἰδών κτλ. Pi. Fr. 137.1, cf. Emp. 132, S. El. 160 (lyr.), etc.: c. gen., ὄλβιαι ὀρχηθμοῦ AP 9.189 ; ὄλβιε καὶ ζωῆς, ὄλβιε καὶ θανάτου Epigr.Gr. 243.15 (Pergam.).

data.quote: ὄλβιε καὶ ζωῆς, ὄλβιε καὶ θανάτου

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom. (only in Od.) always in neut. pl., θεοὶ δέ τοι ὄ. δοῖεν may they give thee rich gifts, Od. 8.413 ; φίλα δῶρα, τά μοι θεοὶ . . ὄ. ποιήσειαν may they make them prosperous, 13.42 (also as Adv., τοῖσιν θεοὶ ὄ. δοῖεν ζωέμεναι happily, 7.148) ; so in Hdt., πάντα μεγάλα . . καὶ ὄ. 1.30 ; εἴπας πολλὰ καὶ ὄ. ib. 31 ; ταῦτα τὰ -ώτατά σφι νενόμισται ib. 216. Adv. -ίως S. OC 1720 (lyr.) : irreg. Sup. ὄλβιστος, η, ον, Call. Lav.Pall. 117, AP 7.164 ( Antip. Sid.), 1 ( Alc. Mess.), 12.56 ( Mel.), etc. : regul. Comp. and Sup. ὀλβιώτερος, ὀλβιώτατος, Hdt. 1.32, 30, 216.—Poet. word, rare in Att. Prose, as Pl. Prt. 337d ( Sup.), Plu. Adul. 2.58e, and Com., as Ar. Ec. 1131.
happy in his own conceit, said of Archytas, Bion ap. D.L. 4.52.
leaning towards the rich, ποδάγρα Luc. Trag. 194.
one who makes prosperous, Dioscorus in PLit.Lond. 981i7 (pl.).

definition: ὀλβοδότειρα, ἡ, fem. of sq., E. Ba. 419 (lyr.), Opp. C. 1.45.

children.definition: giver of wealth, cj. Pierson in Them. Or. 13.178b.

definition: ὀλβοδότης, ου, Dor. ὀλβο-δότας, α, ὁ,

children.definition: giver of bliss or wealth, E. Ba. 573 (lyr.), Epic.Alex. Adesp. 9 vi 6 ( ὀλβιότα Pap.), Epigr.Gr. 978.10 ( Philae), IG 42(1).424,425 ( Epid., iii A. D.), Orph. H. 68.8 :—fem. ὀλβο-δότις, ιδος, ib. 27.9.
nursed amid wealth, Κῆρες Pi. Fr. 277.
money-bag, Cerc. 10.
of a wealthy house, Man. 4.504.
live a prosperous life, Man. 4.581.

happiness, bliss, esp. worldly happiness, weal, ἀλλʼ οὔ μοι τοιοῦτον ἐπέκλωσαν θεοὶ ὄ. Od. 3.208, cf. 4.208 ; Ζεὺς δʼ αὐτὸς νέμει ὄ. ἀνθρώποισιν 6.188 ; ὄλβῳ τε πλούτῳ τε Il. 16.596, Od. 14.206, cf. Emp. 119 : freq. in Lyr., as Pi. O. 6.72, B. 3.92, and Trag., as A. Pers. 164, 252, 709, al. ; ὁ πρὶν παλαιὸς ὄ. S. OT 1282, cf. Plu. Per. 12 : rarely in pl., ἐν Διὸς κήποις ἀροῦσθαι . . εὐδαίμονας ὄ. S. Fr. 320 (lyr.).—Poet. word, used by Hdt. 1.32, 86, X. Cyr. 1.5.9, 4.2.44 and 46, Ar. Av. 421, Hp. Ep. 3, 5, LXX Si. 30.15. (Perh. cogn. with Lith. algà (I.-E. olgṷā) ‘wage’.)

data.quote: ἀλλʼ οὔ μοι τοιοῦτον ἐπέκλωσαν θεοὶ ὄ.
Ζεὺς δʼ αὐτὸς νέμει ὄ. ἀνθρώποισιν
ἐν Διὸς κήποις ἀροῦσθαι . . εὐδαίμονας ὄ.

children.definition: bringing bliss or wealth, θεοί E. IA 596 (anap.).

definition: ὀλεθρεία or ὀλεθρ-ία, ἡ, = sq., LXX Es. 8.13 (E 21), 3 Ma. 4.2.

children.definition: destruction, LXX Jo. 17.13.
slay, destroy, LXX Ex. 12.23, al., Vett.Val. 123.11.
to be on the point of death, Archig. ap. Aët. 9.40.

definition: ὀλέθριος, ον, E. Hec. 1084 (lyr.), Pl. Ep. 334d ; but α, ον Hdt. 6.112, LXX Wi. 18.15, and freq. in Trag. (v. infr.) :—

children.definition: destructive, deadly, ὀ. ἦμαρ the day of destruction, Il. 19.294, 409, cf. ἐλεύθερον ἦμαρ, etc. ; so μανίη πάγχυ ὀ. Hdt. l.c. ; ὀ. μόρος A. Th. 704 ; ἔξω κομίζων ὀλεθρίου πηλοῦ πόδα Id. Ch. 697 ; κότος ὀ. ib. 952 (lyr.) ; ὀλεθρία νύξ S. OC 1683 (lyr.), etc. ; ψῆφος ὀλεθρία a vote of death, A. Th. 198 : in S. Aj. 799, ἔξοδον . . ὀλεθρίαν ἐλπίζει φέρειν seems to be = φέρειν εἰς ὄλεθρον : acc. sg. masc. predicatively used, ἀλλά μʼ ἁ . . θεὸς ὀλέθριον αἰκίζει fatally, ib. 402 (lyr.) :—rare in Prose, as Pl. R. 389d, Gal. 16.522 ; νόσοι Phld. Ir. p.57 W. ( Sup.). Adv. -ίως Eust. 132.16.
γάμοι Πάριδος ὀλέθριοι φίλων bringing ruin on his friends, A. Ag. 1156 (lyr.).
Subst., ψύλλοις ὀλέθριον, name of a fluid, Philum. Ven. 12.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: in danger of death, Hp. Acut. 58 ; lost, undone, S. Tr. 878. Adv. -ίως, ἔχειν Gal. 16.522, al.
rascally, worthless (cf. ὄλεθρος II nisi hoc leg.), Luc. DMort. 3[2].1 codd., Hist.Conscr. 38 codd. ὀλεθρ-ιώδης, ες, gloss on λευγαλέη, Hsch.

ruin, destruction, death, αἰπὺς ὄ. Il. 11.174, al. ; λυγρὸς ὄ. 10.174, al. ; ὄ. ἀδευκής Od. 4.489 ; οἴκτιστος ὄ. 23.79 ; ἵνα ψυχῆς ὤκιστος ὄ. Il. 22.325 ; ὀλέθρου πείρατα, like τέλος θανάτοιο, the consummation of death, 6.143 ; ὄ., opp. γένεσις, Parm. 8.21, 27 ; οὐκ εἰς ὄλεθρον ; as an imprecation, plague take thee! S. OT 430 ; χρημάτων ὀλέθρῳ by destruction of property. Th. 7.27 ; εἶναι ἐν ὀλέθρῳ Antipho 1.29 ; ἐπʼ ὀλέθρῳ τῶν χρωμένων E. Ph. 534 ; ἐκκλησιάζειν ἐπʼ ὀλέθρῳ Ar. Th. 84 ; οὐκ ἐπὶ δουλείᾳ κολάζοντες οὐδʼ ἐπʼ ὀλέθρῳ Pl. R. 471a : pl., Phld. Rh. 2.140S.

data.quote: οὐκ ἐπὶ δουλείᾳ κολάζοντες οὐδʼ ἐπʼ ὀλέθρῳ

children.label: II
children.definition: that which causes destruction, pest, plague, Hes. Th. 326 ; contemptuously of persons, γεγονὼς κακῶς καὶ ἐὼν ὄ. Hdt. 3.142 ; ὑπὸ γερόντων ὀ. Ar. Lys. 325 ; ὄ. ἄνθρωπος Eup. 376, cf. Men. 533.13 ; ὄ. Μακεδών, of Philip, D. 9.31 ; ὄ. γραμματεύς a pestilent scribe, of Aeschines, Id. 18.127 ; τὸν βάσκανον, τὸν δʼ ὄ. the cheat, the pest! Id. 21.209 ; ἀνθρώπους οὐδʼ ἐλευθέρους ἀλλʼ ὀ. Id. 23.202 ; πολλοὶ ὄ. καὶ μεγάλοι Pl. R. 491b.

children.label: III
children.definition: seduction, Ἑλένης E. IA 1382 (troch.).
destruction-bringing, LXX 4 Ma. 8.19.

definition: Ὀλεῖαι, αἱ, female celebrants in ritual at Orchomenos in Boeotia, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.299e.
ὀλέκω, impf. without augm. ὄλεκον Il. 11.150 ; Iterat. ὀλέκεσκον (v.l. ὀλέεσκον) 19.135 :— pres. ὀλέσκω Phot., Suid. :—

children.definition: ruin, destroy, kill, Hom. always in last sense, and mostly of men, οἱ δʼ ἀλλήλους ὀλέκουσιν Il. 18.172, cf. 15.249, Theoc. 22.108, etc. ; but in Od. 22.305, of birds which prey on smaller birds, οἱ δέ τε τὰς ὀλέκουσιν ἐπάλμενοι : in Philos., τίκτει τʼ ὀλέκει τε Emp. 17.4 :— Pass., perish, die, esp. a violent death, ὀλέκοντο δὲ λαοί Il. 1.10, cf. 16.17.—Chiefly Ep., used by Trag. only in lyr., once in Act., τί μʼ ὀλέκεις; S. Ant. 1285 (lyr.); twice in Pass., ὀλέκει A. Pr. 563 (anap.); ὠλεκόμαν S. Tr. 1012 (lyr.): later, LXX Jb. 10.16 :— Pass., ib. 17.1.
Phot.

definition: ὄλενον, τό, late form for ὠλένη, Sch. Ar. Pax 442.

children.definition: entirely deserted, κώμη PSI 1.105.10 (ii A. D.).

definition: ὀλερός, ά, όν, Att. for θολερός,

children.definition: impure, turbid, Gal. 19.126, Hsch.
man-destroying, epith. of perjury, ὅρκοι Thgn. 399, Nonn. D. 28.273.
beast-slaying, ὀλεσίθηρος ὠλένας, of Cadmus, E. Ph. 664 (lyr.).
man-destroying, Orph. L. 450.
city-destroying, Tryph. 453, 683.
made of spittle-wasting reed, epith. of the flute in Pratin.Lyr. 1.12 (cj. Bgk. for ὁλοσίαλον κάλαμον).
destroying tyrants, AP 15.50.
destroyer, murderer, Il. 18.114, Alcm. 43, Nic. Th. 735, etc. :—fem. ὀλέτειρα, Batr. 117, Euph. 3, AP 11.424 ( Piso).

definition: ὀλέτης, ου, ὁ, = foreg., Epigr.Gr. 334.15 ( Ilium) :—fem. ὀλέτις, AP 3.7 ( Inscr. Cyzic.), PMag.Par. 1.2860.
ὄλεχθον τὸ μαζονόμον, Hsch. ὄλεχον, v. ὀλβάχιον.
ὀληθείς ὀδυνηθείς, Hsch. ὀλήθη· καὶ τὰ ὅμοια, Id.

children.definition: working the whole day, ἄνδρες prob. in BGU 513.17 (ii A. D.).
weight of 1 1/2 minae, IG 14.2417.4.
bearer of the οὐλαί ( Att. ὀλαί), ὀ. Ἀθηνᾶς IG 3.323.
Hsch. s. vv. ὀλιβάξαι, ὠλίβραξαν ; cf. ὀλισθάζω, ὀλισθράζω.
Hsch.
having few brothers, Vett.Val. 123.7.
want of blood, Arist. PA 651b11.
scant of blood, Hp. Oss. 13, Arist. PA 651b9, al. ; ὀλιγαιμότατον ὁ χαμαιλέων ib. 692a21.
Arist. PA 692a24.
but few times, seldom, Hp. VM 9, Epid. 1.4.4 [1.26.δʹ], E. Or. 393, Th. 6.38, Pl. Phlb. 52c, etc. ; ὀ. καὶ ὀλιγαχοῦ Arist. Rh. 1404b29 :—a form ὀλιγάκι is cited in EM 172.6.
scant of vines, νῆσος AP 9.413 ( Antiphil.).
quickness in rising, Sch. Ptol. Tetr. 119.
quick in rising, of a zodiacal sign, Vett.Val. 136.7, Heph.Astr. 2.11, Ps.- Ptol. Centil. 52.
to be scant of men, D.S. 15.63, Plu. Publ. 11, D.C. 49.1.
scantiness of men, Str. 14.1.10, Plu. Def.orac. 2.413f, Philostr. VA 3.30.
scant of men, οἶκοι J. BJ 4.3.5 ; βασιλεία Palaeph. 31 ( 32).
Theagen. 17 ; ἐὰν ἱερὰ -ωπῇ are short of their number of priests, PGnom. 85 (ii A. D.) :— Med., J. AJ 11.5.8.
Th. 1.11, X. Mem. 2.7.2, etc. : pl., Pl. Lg. 780b.
scanty meal, Alexandr.Magn. ap. Plu. Alex. 22, Sanit. 2.127b.
to be contented with little, Aesop. 384, dub. cj. in Gp. 14.7.25.
contented with little, Luc. Tim. 57 ; τὸ ὀ., = sq., ib. 54.
contentment with little, Suid.
scarcity of bread, EM 621.47, Suid.
to be a member of an oligarchy, οἱ -οῦντες Arist. Pol. 1300a8 :— Pass., to be governed by the few, be under an oligarchy, Th. 5.31, 8.63, 76, Pl. R. 552b, al.
oligarch, of the Decemviri, D.H. 11.43.

definition: ὀλιγαρχία, Ion. -ιη IG 12(8).262.3 ( Thasos, v B. C.), etc. : ἡ :—

children.definition: oligarchy, government in the hands of a few families or persons, Hdt. 3.82, 5.92.βʹ, etc. ; of the time of the Four Hundred, Th. 8.72 ; or of the Thirty, And. 1.99, Pl. Ap. 32c ; ἄκρατος ὀ. Arist. Pol. 1273b37, al., cf. Pl. R. 550c sq., Plt. 291e.
Ὀλιγαρχία, personified in a statue, Sch. Aeschin. 1.39.

oligarchical, ὀ. κόσμος Th. 8.72 ; ξυνωμοσία Id. 6.60 ; δίκαιον, νόμος, Arist. Pol. 1280a8, 1281a37 ; πολιτεῖαι ib. 1288a22 ; [πόλις] ib. 1316b7 ; τοῦτο -ώτερον ib. 1281a33. Adv. -κῶς Pl. R. 555a, D. 15.33.
inclined or devoted to oligarchy, And. 4.16, Lys. 25.8, Pl. R. 545a, al. ; οἱ ὀ., opp. οἱ δημοκρατικοί, Arist. Pol. 1280a27.
having but little arable land, AP 6.226 ( Leon., ὀλιγόλαυξ cod.Pal. ; ὀλιγῶλαξ ( Dor.) Brunck).
from some few parts, τῆς Λιβύης Hdt. 3.96, cf. Arist. EE 1221a24.
in a few places, πάνυ που ὀ. Pl. Chrm. 160c, cf. Arist. Rh. 1404b29.
locust, Phot., Suid.
have little, Theol.Ar. 29 :— Subst. ὀλῐγ-εξία, in pl., Nicom. Ar. 1.14 (v.l. ὀλιγοεξίαι).
of or lasting a few days, ζωή Hp. Art. 63 ; πυρετοὶ -ήμεροι κτείνοντες Id. Fract. 11 : Comp., Id. Acut. 17 : Sup., Id. Art. 63.
lasting a short time, τρῖψις prob. in Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.23.16.
having little power, in feeble case, powerless, κεῖτʼ ὀλιγηπελέων Od. 5.457 ; ὀλιγηπελέουσά περ ἔμπης 19.356, cf. Il. 15.245 ; cf. κακηπελέων.
weak, powerless, AP 7.380 ( Crin.), Opp. H. 1.767.
weakness, faintness, Od. 5.468 ; cf. εὐηπελία, κακηπελία.
Nic. Th. 284.

definition: ὀλιγήριος, ον, = foreg., ὀ. σῆμα a

children.definition: small tombstone, AP 7.656 ( Leon.) : or perh. compd. of ὀλίγος, ἠρίον.
want of arable land, AP 6.98 ( Zon.).
with little corn, or with a small bread-basket, opp. εὐσίπυος, AP 6.288 ( Leon.), 300 ( Id.).
most seldom, opp. πλειστάκις, prob. in Gal. 18(1).649.
Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.103.
light in weight, Paul.Aeg. 3.76.
short-lived, Arist. HA 605b24 ( Comp.), LXX Jb. 11.2, 14.1, S.E. M. 1.73.
with little discretion, Adam. 2.31.
Hsch., Phot.
with few joints, [κάλαμος] Thphr. HP 4.11.11.
production of few offspring, opp. πολυγονία, Pl. Prt. 321b.
producing few offspring, ζῷα ὀ., opp. πολύγονα, Hdt. 3.108, Arist. HA 558b28 ; unprolific, Vett.Val. 5.25 ; of plants, Thphr. HP 8.4.4 : Comp. -ώτερος Arist. HA 570b32.
composed of few letters, opp. πολυγράμματος, Phld. Po.Herc. 994.34.
consuming or spending little, Suid. s.v. εὐτελής.
wanting little, Posidon. 59J., M.Ant. 5.5 ; -δεεστέρα εὐδόκησις ‘cheaper’ popularity, Plb. 16.20.4 : Sup., Ph. 1.116.
contentment with little, Ph. 1.307, al.
having few trees, Sch.D.T. p.152 H.
living on little, Cephisodor. ap. Caryst. 7.
having but few slaves, Str. 16.4.26.

definition: ὀλιγοδρανέω, ( δραίνω) in Ep. pres. part. -έων,

children.definition: able to do little, feeble, powerless, Il. 15.246, 16.843, 22.337 (never in Od.) : also in late Prose, -οῦσα ἡ διάνοια Ph. 1.460, cf. 2.573, Jul. Caes. 331b : pres. ind. -οῦσιν Iamb. Myst. 2.8.
of little might, feeble, Ar. Av. 686, Luc. Trag. 324.
weakness, feebleness, A. Pr. 548 (anap.).
to be retarded, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.102.7b.
have little power, Sch.D Il. 22.337.
ineffectual, Sch. Opp. H. 1.623.
producing but little oil, Thphr. CP 6.8.5.
of little strength, σῶμα Hp. Loc.Hom. 43.
of few years, χρόνος, ἄνθρωπος, οἶνος, Poll. 1.58.
fewness of years, youth, X. Cyr. 1.4.3.
with few branches, Thphr. HP 1.8.2.
possession of little heat, Mich. in PN 132.22.
having little heat, of cold-blooded animals, Arist. PA 652b25, GA 718b37, al. ; of the spleen, Id. PA 670b7, etc.
to be of little courage, Eust. 159.17.
with few fibres, Thphr. HP 5.1.5.
brooking no delay, ἰητρική Hp. Loc.Hom. 44.
with few reeds or stalks, Thphr. CP 4.11.4 ( Comp.).
bear little fruit, Str. Chr. 2.3, Ptol. Tetr. 221.
bearing little fruit, Thphr. CP 2.11.10, D.H. 1.37, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. inc. 7.4.
with few stalks, Thphr. HP 7.8.2.
with small horns, Gp. 18.1.3.
little-moving, Porph. ap. Stob. 2.8.41. Phlp. in Cat. 166.9.
with few branches, Thphr. HP 1.5.1.
prate little, Eust. 1278.12.
having learnt little, Eustr. in EN 256.24.
small compass, τῆς ἀναγραφῆς PGnom. Prooem. (dat. written -ίᾳ).
the having few feet, Eust. 353.39.
receiving small wages, Pl. Ep. 348a ( Comp.).
speaking little, Democr. 274.
with few dreams, ὕπνοι Iamb. VP 25.114.
with little wood, shrubby, ῥωπεῖον AP 6.226 ( Leon.) ; bearing little timber, Str. Chr. 12.7.
fewness of children, Muson. Fr. 15Ap.77H.
with few children, Pl. Lg. 930a.
of little faith, Ev.Matt. 8.26, al., Sext. Sent. 6.
scant of breath, Hsch. s.v. ἀζαλές.
make few, diminish, LXX Si. 48.2.
with thin grey hair, Hsch. s.v. σπαρνοπόλιος.
sparingness in labour, idleness, Plb. 16.28.3.
working little, D.H. Dem. 51.
moderation in drinking, Aret. CD 1.4, Luc. Par. 16 ; but ὀλῐγο-ποτίη Aret. CD 1.2.
drink little, Arist. PA 670b15, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.224d.
one who drinks little, Ath. 10.419a, Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 5.27.13.
drinking little, Arist. HA 593b29, al. ; ἄδιψα καὶ ὀ. Id. PA 669a34.
a retired life, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.176.
averse to business, retiring, opp. πολυπράγμων, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.176.
with few feathers, Arist. HA 486b 11.

definition: ὀλιγοπύθμην, ενος, ὁ, ἡ, sine expl., Theognost. Can. 86.

children.definition: with few grains of wheat, Thphr. CP 4.11.4.
with few roots, Thphr. HP 1.6.3, Gp. 4.1.12.

definition: ὀλίγος [ῐ], η, ον, later ὀλίος (q.v.), of Size,

children.definition: little, small, freq. in Hom., rarer later, opp. μέγας, σάκος Il. 14.376 ; κῦμα Od. 10.94, etc. ; ὀλίγῃ ὀπί with small, low voice, 14.492 ; of stature, 9.515 ; ὀ. κῶρος Theoc. 1.47 ; οὐκ ὀλίγης αἷμα βοὸς κέχυται Call. Aet. Oxy. 2080.85 [Fr. 43.83 Pf.] ; of Space, ὀ. χῶρος Il. 10.161, etc. ; of Time, χρόνος 19.157, 23.418, Pi. N. 7.38, etc. ; ἐν βραχεῖ κὠλίγῳ χρόνῳ S. Fr. 646 (cf. IV. 3).
ὀ. δόσις Od. 6.208 ; οὖρα ὀλίγα not copious, Hp. Epid. 1.2 ; ὑποστάσιες ὀλίγαι slight sediments, ib. 17 ; ὀ. καὶ οὐδέν little or nothing, Pl. Ap. 23a ; οὐδὲν ἢ ὀ. Arist. PA 651b17.
ὀ. καὶ μέγας of low and high degree, Callin. 1.17.
weak, ἀθυμοτέρη καὶ ὀλιγωτέρη φύσις Hp. Virg. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: few, or of Quantity, little, not in Hom., freq. in Att., Ar. Av. 1417, Eq. 717, etc., but rare in Trag., as ὀλίγα κακά A. Pers. 330.—The governing body in Oligarchies and the oligarchical party in Democracies was called οἱ ὀ., Th. 6.38, 8.9, etc. ; ἡ ὑπὸ τῶν ὀ. δυναστεία, αἱ διὰ τῶν ὀ. δυναστεῖαι, Pl. Plt. 291d, D. 60.25 ; ἑνὸς καὶ πλήθους τὸ ὀ. μέσον Pl. Plt. 303a.

data.quote: ἑνὸς καὶ πλήθους τὸ ὀ. μέσον

children.definition: inf., ὀλίγους . . στρατιῇ τῇ Μήδων συμβαλεῖν too few to engage . . , Hdt. 6.109, cf. 7.207 ; μὴ . . αἱ σφέτεραι δέκα νῆες ὀλίγαι ἀμύνειν ὦσιν Th. 1.50.

data.quote: μὴ . . αἱ σφέτεραι δέκα νῆες ὀλίγαι ἀμύνειν ὦσιν

children.label: III
children.definition: ὀλίγον as Adv., a little, slightly, little, with Verbs, ὀ. παρακλίνας Il. 23.424, cf. 11.52, 12.452 ; φροντίσας E. Cyc. 163 ; ὀ. τοῦ ποιήματος προελθών Pl. Prt. 339d : also neut. pl., ἠκροβολίσαντο ὀλίγα Th. 3.73.

ὀλίγον προγενέστερος Il. 23.789 ; ὀ. ἧσσον Od. 15.365 ; στιβαρώτερον οὐκ ὀ. περ 8.187 ; φέρτερος οὐκ ὀ. περ Il. 19.217 ; ὀ. τι πρότερον, v.l. for ὀλίγῳ, Hdt. 4.79, 81, cf. Pl. Plt. 262b, etc. ; ὀ. ὕστερον Id. Grg. 454b, etc. ; but ὀλίγῳ is more freq. in Prose, Hdt. ll.cc. (with v.l.), 7.113, al., Pl. Grg. 460c, R. 327c, etc.

ὀλίγου δεῖν almost (v. δεῖ II); ὀλίγου ἐδέησε καταλαβεῖν wanted but little of overtaking, Hdt. 7.10.γʹ : hence ὀλίγου alone, within a little, all but, almost, ὀλίγου σε κύνες διεδηλήσαντο Od. 14.37, cf. Ar. Ach. 348, 381, Nu. 722, Lys. 14.17, Pl. Prt. 361b, D. 19.334, etc. ; ὀ. ἅπαντες Pl. Ap. 22b ; ὀ. ἐς χιλίους close upon 1000, Th. 4.124 ; ὀ. ἦλθεν ἑλεῖν (v. infr. 9) Paus. 1.13.6.
διʼ ὀλίγου at a short distance, E. Ph. 1098, Th. 2.89, 3.21, dub. in A. Th. 762 (lyr.) ; for (during) a short time, Th. 1.77, 2.85, 3.43 ; within or after a short time, Id. 6.11, 47, 7.39, etc. ; but

children.label: b
children.definition: διʼ ὀλίγων in few words, Pl. Phlb. 31d, etc. ; v. infr. VI.2.

ἐν ὀλίγῳ ( χώρῳ is added in Hdt. 9.70) in a small space, within small compass, E. Supp. 1126 (lyr.) ; ἐν ὀ. στρατοπεδευομένοις Th. 4.26 ; κυκλωθέντων ἐν ὀ. ib. 96 ; εἰς ταὐτὸ πάντα . . ἁθροίσαντʼ ἐν ὀ. D. 3.18 ; also ἐν ὀ. (sc. χρόνῳ) for a brief time, Pi. P. 8.92 ; but also, in a short time, quickly, ἔγνων καὶ περὶ τῶν ποιητῶν ἐν ὀ. τοῦτο Pl. Ap. 22b, cf. Th. 4.55, Act.Ap. 26.28.

data.quote: εἰς ταὐτὸ πάντα . . ἁθροίσαντʼ ἐν ὀ.
ἔγνων καὶ περὶ τῶν ποιητῶν ἐν ὀ. τοῦτο

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐν ὀλίγοις one among few, i.e. exceedingly, remarkably, ποταμὸς ἐν ὀ. μέγας Hdt. 4.52 ; ἐν ὀλίγοισι Περσέων . . ἀνὴρ δόκιμος Id. 9.41 : freq. in later writers, Plu. Pomp. 10, Hld. 3.1 ; so σὺν ὀλίγοις, v. infr. 10.
ἐξ ὀλίγου at short notice, suddenly, ἐξ ὀ. καὶ διʼ ὀργῆς Th. 2.11, cf. 61, 4.108, etc.
ἐς ὀλίγον, like παρʼ ὀλίγον, within a little, ἐς ὀ. ἀφίκετο τὸ στράτευμα νικηθῆναι ib. 129.

ἐπʼ ὀλίγον for a short time, Hp. Prorrh. 1.26, Plot. 4.4.29, Gp. 7.12.22, 10.7.10, etc. ; a little at a time, Hp. VC 18 ; εἴρηται ἐν τῷ [βιβλίῳ] ἐπʼ ὀλίγον a little way on, near the beginning, Gal. 15.428.

κατʼ ὀλίγον by little and little, Th. 1.69, Pl. Ti. 85d, Luc. Nec. 11, etc. ; ἐκ τοῦ κατʼ ὀ. D.S. 15.34, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. 1.2.6 : but the Adj. freq. takes the gender and number of its Subst., κατʼ ὀλίγους Hdt. 2.93, 8.113 ; οὗτοι κατʼ ὀλίγους γινόμενοι ἐμάχοντο fought few at a time, in small parties, Id. 9.102, cf. Pl. Tht. 197d ; κατʼ ὀλίγον μαχεῖται (sc. τὸ πλῆθος αὐτῶν) Th. 4.10.
μετʼ ὀλίγον τούτων shortly after . . , X. HG 1.1.2.
παρʼ ὀλίγον with little to spare, only just, ἀπέφυγες E. IT 870 (lyr.) ; to within a short distance of, παρʼ ὀ. ἦλθε . . ἐκπεσεῖν Plb. 2.55.4, cf. 18.46.12 ; but

children.label: b
children.definition: παρʼ ὀ. ποιεῖσθαι hold of small account, X. An. 6.6.11.
σὺν ὀλίγοις, = ἐν ὀλίγοις, ἐπαινεθῆναι Plu. Galb. 3 ; v. supr. IV. 3b.

children.label: V
children.definition: Adv. ὀλίγως is rare, 2 Ep.Pet. 2.18, Aq. Is. 10.7 ; οὐκ ὀ. AP 12.205 ( Strat.).

Comp. is commonly supplied by μείων, ἥσσων, or ἐλάσσων (qq.v.) ; the older form ὀλείζων (fr. *ὀλειγ-yων) is found in Hom., λαοὶ δʼ ὑπʼ ὀλείζονες ἦσαν ( ὑπολίζονες codd.) Il. 18.519 ; so in Att. Inscrr., IG 1(2).76.8 (written ὄλεζον ib. 63.17, al.) ; τοῖσι . . ὀλείζοσι μυστηρίοισιν ib. 6.76, cf. 95 ; ὀλείζους is prob. in X. Ath. 2.1 ( μείζους codd.) ; so in Alexandrian Poets, Call. Jov. 72 ( ὀλίζοσι codd.), AP 9.521 ; ἐς ὀλίζονας ἀστέρας ἄρκτου Poet. ap. Theodos. in Hilgard Exc. ex Hdn. p.19 ; also ὀλίζωνες Nic. Th. 123, ὀλίζωνα ib. 372 ; ὀλιζότερος is found in Id. Al. 479, Opp. C. 3.65, 394, cf. ὀλιζόω ; ὀλιγώτερος is found in Hp. Virg. 1 (with the sense weaker, v. supr. I.4), S.E. M. 1.70, App. Pun. 42, Mith. 24, Ael. NA 2.42, 6.51.

Sup. ὀλίγιστος, η, ον, always of Number or Quantity, Il. 19.223, Hes. Op. 723, IG 1(2).54.7, Ar. Ra. 115, Pl. 628, Pl. R. 473b, al. ; ὀλιγίστου, Sup. of ὀλίγου (cf. IV. I), very nearly, Phot., Hsch. (ubi ὀλιγωστοῦ) ; ὀλίγιστον as Adv., least, very little, Pl. R. 587b ; τὸ ὀ. at least, Id. Prm. 149a ; ὡς ὀλίγιστα Id. Grg. 510a, Lg. 953a (v.l. ὀλιγοστά) ; ἐν ὀλιγίστῳ διασαφῶν Eust. 1262.54 ; so διʼ ὀλιγίστων Pl. Ep. 351d (interpol.). (Aspirated in papyri of ii- iii A.D., as μεθʼ ὁλίγον BGU 388.11, cf. 146.10.)
with little flesh, Luc. Abd. 29, Gal. 14.45, Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 10.18.7 ( Comp.).
to be faint, B. 5.152.
with little strength, Sch. Opp. H. 1.623.
eat little, Hp. Fract. 27, Plu. Sanit. 2.129f.
small eating, moderation in food, Arist. Pol. 1272a22, Pr. 863b24, Thphr. Lass. 17, Sor. 1.65, etc.
eating little or moderately, Pherecr. 1, Phryn.Com. 23.
having little seed, Arist. GA 725b29, Thphr. HP 7.4.4 ( Comp.).

definition: ὀλιγόσπορος, ον, = foreg., of persons, Vett.Val. 14.23 ; of a part of the zodiac. Heph.Astr. 1.1.

children.definition: of few stadia, πορθμός Eust. ad D.P. 64.
the consisting of few lines, AP 4.2.6 ( Phil.).
consisting of few lines, Call. Aet. Oxy. 2079.9 [Fr. 1.9 Pf.], D.L. 7.165.
with few companions, ὀ. ὁρμᾶν Beros. ap. J. AJ 10.11.1, cf. Plu. Caes. 49, Ant. 51, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: for the smallest space of time, S. Ant. 625 codd. ( -ιστον Bgk., Jebb), v.l. in Arist. Metaph. 1053a9 ; ὀλιγωστοῦ Hsch. (cf. ὀλίγος VI.2).
fewness of syllables, Eust. 25.35.
of few syllables, D.H. Comp. 12, Eust. 836.17.
sparing of conjunctions, ἁρμονία D.H. Comp. 22.
of small body or bulk, Comp. -ώτερος Sch. Pl. ap. Plot. de Pulcr. p.536 (ed. Creuzer, Heidelb.1814).
Ptol. Tetr. 189.
(Max.Tyr. 6.1 ( Sup.).

definition: ὀλιγότης, ητος, ἡ, opp. πλῆθος in all senses :

children.definition: fewness, Pl. Lg. 678c, Arist. Metaph. 984a10, al., LXX Ps. 101(102).23, Plu. Alex. 20 ; fewness of rulers, Arist. Pol. 1279b27.
smallness, scantiness, Pl. R. 591e, Lg. 745d ; of food, Epicur. Fr. 456.
shortness, Pl. Tht. 158d.
feebleness of voice, Poll. 6.145.
quote less than the true price, IG 5(1).1421.14 ( Cyparissia).
bring forth few, Arist. GA 772b2.
the bringing forth of few, Arist. GA 771b6.
bringing forth few, Arist. PA 688a32, GA 753a31.
having few hairs, Arist. HA 498b17.
little nourishment, Gal. 6.209, Sor. 1.65, Alex.Trall. Febr. 3.
giving little nourishment, Hp. Prorrh. 2.3, Thphr. CP 3.13.4, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.120e, Gal. 17(2).368 : Comp., -ώτερον γάλα Sor. 1.117.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., taking little nourishment, Arist. PA 682a21, Pr. 898b21 ; abstemious, of athletes in training, dub. in Delph. 3(1).474 (iii B.C.).
scant of water, Thphr. HP 6.7.6 ( Sup.).
containing little matter, Eust. 1379.43.
sleep little, Eust. 1649.32.
little or short sleep, Iamb. VP 16.69, 31.188.
taking little or short sleep, App. Hisp. 71(74) ( Sup.), Gal. 10.538.
Ar. Pax 28.
Hp. Vict. 2.49.
Suid.
fewness of friends, Antipho Fr. 75, Arist. Rh. 1386a10.
that can bear but little, of weak wine, that will bear but little water, Hp. Acut. 56, Gal. 6.807, cf. Sch. Ar. Pl. 854.
little eloquent, Sch. Pi. O. 3.81.

definition: ὀλιγόφρων, ὁ, ἡ, φρον, τό, gen. ονος,

children.definition: of small understanding, Ph. 2.70, al., Plu. Garr. 2.504b, Poll. 4.14. Adv. -όνως ib. 15.
having few leaves, Thphr. HP 1.10.8.
with little tone, prob. gloss on ἄφωνα, Aristid.Quint. 1.20.
yielding little, Thphr. HP 8.4.4 ; πρὸς τὴν γονήν, = ὀλιγόσπερμος, Arist. GA 757a21 ( Comp.).
fewness of strings, Plu. Mus. 2.1135d, 1137a.
with few strings, Plu. Mus. 2.1137b (cj. Volkmann for τρίχορδα).
of or with little money, παρακαταθήκη Ph. 1.287, al.
take a short time to rise, Ptol. Tetr. 132, Heph.Astr. 2.11.

definition: ὀλιγοχρόνιος, ον, also α, ον AP 7.648 ( Leon.), Aret. CA 2.1 :—

children.definition: of short duration, short-lived, Thgn. 1020, Mimn. 5.5, Democr. 285, Antipho Soph. 51, Hdt. 1.38, Pl. Phd. 87c, 87d, Arist. Pol. 1315b11, etc. ; opp. πολυχρόνιος, Phld. Sign. 23.

children.label: II
children.definition: within a short time, κίνδυνος (v.l. θάνατος) Hp. Prog. 7. Adv. -ίως Gal. 18(2).243, Iamb. Protr. 20.
shortness of time, Thphr. CP 2.12.1, Ptol. Tetr. 10, Heph.Astr. 2.11 ; shortness of life, Ptol. Tetr. 115, Vett.Val. 147.3, Paul.Al. H. 2.
M.Ant. 5.10 codd. ( -χρόνια Casaubon).
having little gold, poor in gold, Poll. 3.109.
with little juice, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.120e, Dsc. 2.182.

definition: ὀλιγόχυμος, ον, = foreg., Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.78.

children.definition: small in area, Anon. in Rh. 7.16.
to be faint, Isoc. 19.39.

children.label: II
children.definition: become discouraged, PPetr. 2p.135 (iii B.C.), LXX Nu. 21.4, al., EM 395.31.
to be worried, περὶ τῆς ἐνκατοχῆς μου, περὶ τοῦ ἐνοικίου, UPZ 63.1 (ii B.C.), POxy. 1294.13 (ii/iii A.D.) ; ὠλιγοψύχησεν ἕως τοῦ ἀποθανεῖν LXX Jd. 16.16 :— Med., UPZ 78.10 (ii B.C.) ; cf. ὁλοψυχέω.
Hp. Mul. 1.8, Epid. 7.47.

children.label: II
children.definition: faint-heartedness, LXX Ex. 6.9, Ps. 54(55).8.
faint-hearted, feeble-minded, LXX Is. 35.4, 54.6, 1 Ep.Thess. 5.14, Artem. 3.5.
lessen, diminish, ἐν ἀπειλῇ -ώσεις γῆν LXX Hb. 3.12 ; ἔτη ἀσεβῶν -ωθήσεται ib. Pr. 10.27 ; ὠλιγώθη ἡ ψυχὴ αὐτοῦ his soul was grieved, ib. Jd. 10.16, al.
lasting a few hours, ἡμέρα Sch. D.P. 30.

definition: ὀλιγωρέω, aor. 1 written ὠλιώρησα IG 12(8).53.5 ( Imbros, ii B.C.) : —

children.definition: esteem little or lightly, make small account of, c. gen., X. Mem. 2.4.3, Pl. Ap. 28d, Phd. 68c, etc.
take no heed, Th. 5.9, 6.91, Isoc. 9.41, etc. ; εἴς τι Arist. Rh. 1379b28 :— Pass., Pl. La. 180b ; τοῖς οὕτως ὠλιγωρημένοις D. 17.21.
neglect, τὴν ἄμπελον PAvrom. 1.25 (i B.C.) : c. inf., intermit, neglect to do something, Gal. 6.243.
act of negligence, Arist. VV 1251b22.
Arist. VV 1251a5 (pl.), Them. Or. 10.136a.
one must esteem lightly, Isoc. Ep. 9.18, Aristox. Fr.Hist. 15.

an esteeming lightly, contempt, ὑπό τε ὕβριος καὶ -ίης Hdt. 1.106, cf. 6.137 ; ἐν ὀλιγωρίᾳ ποιεῖσθαι, = ὀλιγωρεῖν, Th. 4.5 ; ἐς ὀλιγωρίαν τραπέσθαι τινός Id. 2.52 ; ὀ. πρός τι D. 54.39 ; περί τινος Plb. 11.9.2, cf. Arist. Rh. 1378b10 ; εἴς τι Id. Pol. 1315a18 : in pl., Isoc. 7.51.
neglect of duty, negligence, Decret. ap. D. 18.74 ; διακεχυμέναι πρὸς -ίαν διατριβαί Eun. Hist. p.257 D.

little-caring, lightly-esteeming, contemptuous, of persons, χαλεπός τε καὶ ὀ. Hdt. 3.89 ; οὐδεὶς οὔτε γέρων οὔτε ὀ. οὕτως D. 24.208, etc. ; σοβαρὸς καὶ ὀ. τρόπος Id. 59.37 : c. gen., τὴν εἰρήνην, ἧς οὐδεὶς ἂν ἐπιδείξειεν . . ὀλιγωροτέραν τῶν Ἑλλήνων a peace more regardless of Hellenic rights, Isoc. 12.106. Adv. -ρως neglectfully, carelessly, ὀ. καὶ ῥᾳθύμως φέρειν D. 59.111 ; ὀ. καὶ πάντοθεν λαμβάνειν Arist. EN 1121b1 ; ὀ. ἔχειν to be careless, negligent, περὶ τὰς ἐπιθυμίας Pl. Phd. 68c, X. HG 1.6.20 ; τινος with regard to . . , Lys. 26.9, Is. 3.37, etc.; περί τινος Arist. Rh.Al. 1433a2 ; ὀ. διακεῖσθαι Lys. 1.3 ; ὀ. διακεῖσθαι πρός τινα or τι Pl. Alc. 2.149a, Isoc. 15.5 ; ὀ. ἔχειν πρὸς ἅπασαν αἰσχύνην Aeschin. 1.67.

data.quote: οὐδεὶς οὔτε γέρων οὔτε ὀ. οὕτως

children.label: II
children.definition: scornful, ὀλίγωρον . . πεποίηκάς τι Nicom.Com. 1.2.
of little use, S.E. M. 1.296: Comp., Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 8.3.3.
make less, diminish, Orac. ap. Eus. PE 5.22 :— Pass., Hsch.
make into a single whole, Olymp. in Phd. p.86 N.

universal, general, absolute (opp. γενικός or μερικός), ὁ. ζωή Olymp. in Phd. p.17 N., cf. Procl. Inst. 60, 70, Simp. in Cat. 58.30, in de An. 72.13, Dam. Pr. 56, al. Adv. -ῶς OGI 669.64 ( Egypt, i A. D.), Hsch., cj. in Gal. 19.194 : Comp. -ώτερον Phlp. in APο. 121.6.
universality, Simp. in Cat. 113.17.
sheaves of barley, also = λῖνος (Cypr.), Hsch. ὀλινύει· λήγει, ἀργεῖ, prob. in Id. ( = ἐλινύει).

definition: ὀλίος, later form of ὀλίγος, first in Pl. Com. 168, Rhinth. 2, 8, then in Inscrr. and Pap. from 300 B.C., PPetr. 2p.2 (iii B. C.), IG 2(2).1227.8 (ii B. C.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἀπόλλων Ὄλιος, v. οὔλιος.
loaf in the shape of an ὄλισβος, Com.Adesp. 1094.
penis coriaceus, Cratin. 316, Ar. Lys. 109, Fr. 320.13.
Comp. -ωτέρα Gal. 18(2).624 :—also ὀλισθός, Hdn.Gr. 1.147.

definition: ὀλισθάνω (also ὀλισθ-αίνω Arist. Pr. 936a15, 939a26, A.R. 1.377, etc., but never in good Att.): fut. ὀλισθήσω LXX Pr. 14.19, Nonn. D. 36.458 : pf. ὠλίσθηκα Hp. Art. 57, 65 : plpf. ὠλισθήκειν (v. infr. II.1) : aor. ὠλίσθησα AP 9.125, Str. Chr. 4.8 (p.476 Kr.), etc. ; 3 pl. ὠλίσθησαν Nic. Fr. 74.51 (codd. Ath., ὠλίσθηναν cj. Schn.) ; part. fem. ὀλισθήνασα Id. Al. 89: but in classical Att. always aor. 2 ὤλισθον, part. ὀλισθών, inf. ὀλισθεῖν ( Hom. only in Il., in Ep. 3 sg. ὄλισθε, v. infr.) :—

children.definition: slip, fall upon a slippery path, ἔνθʼ Αἴας μὲν ὄλισθε θέων Il. 23.774 ; ἐκ δέ οἱ ἧπαρ ὄλισθεν his liver fell from him, 20.470 ; ἐξ ἀντύγων ὤλισθε he slipped from . . , S. El. 746 ; ὀ. τῆς χειρὸς ὁ σίδηρος Arist. Mech. 854a19 ; νηὸς ὀλισθών AP 9.267 ( Phil.) ; ὐ. εἴσω, ἔξω, of a bone, slip out of the socket on one side or the other, Hp. Fract. 14, 37 ; θαυμαστὰ γὰρ τὸ τόξον ὡς ὀλισθάνει slips, loses its force, S. Fr. 960 : metaph., ὀ. εἰς νοῦσον AP 7.233 ( Apollonid.); ἐς Ἅιδου IG 14.1642 ; in moral sense, make a slip, Ar. Ra. 690 ; in literary sense, εἰς τερατώδεις ὀ. ἀναπλασμούς Metrod. Herc. 831.5.

data.quote: θαυμαστὰ γὰρ τὸ τόξον ὡς ὀλισθάνει

children.definition: slip or glide along, ὀ. ἐν τῷ λάβδα ἡ γλῶττα Pl. Cra. 427b ; βέλος διὰ σαρκὸς ὄλισθεν Theoc. 25.230.

data.quote: ὀ. ἐν τῷ λάβδα ἡ γλῶττα

children.label: II
children.definition: sprain by slipping, ὠλισθήκει τὸν γλουτόν Philostr. VA 3.39, cf. Gym. 14.
make to slip, τὰς διανοίας LXX Si. 3.24.

definition: ὀλισθήεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for ὀλισθηρός, AP 9.443 ( Paul.Sil.).

children.definition: slip, fall, ὑγρὰ -ήματα ὑδάτων Pl. Ti. 43c ; ὀ. γῆς place where a landslip has occurred, J. AJ 15.10.3 ; so ὀ. without γῆς, Inscr.Prien. 42.10,42 (ii B. C.) ; in moral sense, cause of slipping, Plu. Adul. 2.49c.
luxation, Hp. Fract. 14, Heliod. ap. Orib. 49.9.16, Gal. 19.460, etc.
slippery, οἶμος Pi. P. 2.96 (metaph.) ; ἂν . . ὀ. ᾖ τὸ χωρίον X. Eq. 7.15 ; λίθοι Id. An. 4.3.6, etc. ; of mucilage, Hp. Acut. 10, 15 ( Sup.).

children.label: II
children.definition: slippery, hard to catch and keep hold of, Pl. Sph. 231a ( Sup.) ; τύχη AP 10.66 ( Agath.); τὸ ὀ. τῆς διανοίας αὐτῶν Ps.-Luc. Philopatr. 22 ; ὀ. ἱκεσίη AP 5.215 ( Agath.).
liable to slip, πόδες AP 7.542 (Stat. Flacc.) ; ὀλισθηροὶ εἰς πόδας ib. 398 (Antip.) : metaph., πρὸς ὀργὴν ὀ. Plu. Cat.Mi. 1. Adv. -ρῶς, ἔχειν πρός τι Id. Aud.poet. 2.31c.
slipping and falling, Plu. Cons.ux. 611a, QConv. 731f: hence, dislocation, τρόπος ὀλισθήσιος Hp. Fract. 42, Art. 74.
making slippery, Hp. Superf. 7.
make a slip in judgement, Luc. Lex. 19.
labefacio, Gloss.
slipperiness, Hp. Acut. 58, Plb. 15.14.2, etc. ; ὄλισθον ἔχειν, of ground, etc., to be slippery, Luc. Merc.Cond. 42, cf. Anach. 2, Praxagoras ap. Gal. 18(1).7.
Apollod. Poliorc. 150.2: metaph., ὄ. γλώσσης Plu. Garr. 2.510a, cf. (Max.Tyr. 37.4.
snare, μεθύουσι ὀ. οἶνος Poet. ap. Clem.Al. Paed. 2.2.28.

children.label: II
children.definition: an unknown fish with a slippery skin, Opp. H. 1.113.
Epich. 35, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.126.
like a ship of burden, πλοῖον ὁ., = ὁλκάς, Arist. IA 710a19.
ship-caulker, Man. 4.342.
draw, ὅλκασον ( ὥλκασσον Pap.) τὴν τροφὴν ἐκ τοῦ ὕδατος PBaden 49 (ii B. C.) ; cf. ὁλκάζει· ἕλκει, χαλιναγωγεῖ, Hsch.
stern-post of a ship, A.R. 1.1314, Antioch. (?) ap. Poll. 6.100 ; cf. ὁλκεῖον.
drawn along, towed, of a ship (cf. ὁλκάς), Nic. Th. 268 : hence, trailing, dragging, σειρή, of a serpent, ib. 119 ; ἀτραπός ib. 160 ; κακά Lyc. 216.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ὁλκαία, Ion. ὁλκαίη, ἡ, tail, because it is trailed along, Nic. Th. 123, 225, A.R. 4.1614 (v.l. ἀλκαία, which Schn. writes in Nic. ll. cc.).

ship which is towed : hence, trading vessel, merchantman, Pi. N. 5.2, Hdt. 3.135, 7.25, 137, Lys. 32.25 ; ἐν ὁλκάσιν ἢ πλοίοις Th. 7.7, cf. X. Ath. 1.20 ; ὁ. σιταγωγοί Th. 6.44 ; οἰναγωγοί Pherecr. 143.5, cf. Cephisod. 10 : metaph., of women, AP 5.160 ; of Europaʼs bull, Nonn. D. 1.66.
conveyed to the place of building, IG ΙΙ(2).199 A 79 ( Delos, iii B. C.).
ὁλκάς· . . παρʼ Ἀλκμᾶνι ἀειδῶν (i. e. ἀηδών, cf. Hsch. s.v. ὁλκάς), Cyr.Coisl. 394 ( Rh.Mus. 43.451).

large bowl or basin, SIG 869.16 ( Eleusis), Inscr.Olymp. 468.6, Epig. 6, Philem. 17, Men. 73, BCH 35.286 ( Delos, ii B. C.), Πολέμων 1.126 ( Demetrias), Plb. 30.26.1 ( ὁλκίων codd. Ath.), PSI 4.428.62, Plu. Alex. 20 ( ὁλκίον codd.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Ep. form ὁλκήϊον, = ὁλκαῖον, A.R. 4.1609.

definition: ὁλκεύς, έως, pl. ὁλκεῖς· οἳ τὰ ἀμφίβληστρα ἐπισπῶνται, Hsch.

children.definition: drawing, trailing, dragging, e. g. of the hair, A. Supp. 884 ; ἡ τῆς γνάψεως ὁ. the drawing of the carding instrument in fulling cloth, Pl. Plt. 282e ; ἀπὸ μιᾶς ὁ. by one haul or pull, Arist. Mech. 853b1 ; ἡ ὁ. τοῦ ἀρότρου S.E. P. 3.15 : metaph., τοῖς δεινοῖς περὶ λόγων ὁλκήν skilled in drawing words to a false meaning, Pl. Phlb. 57d.
inhalation (of vapour), Hp. Mul. 1.55 ; ὁ. πνεύματος drawing in of the breath, Arist. Spir. 482a15 ; τοῦ αἵματος suction of blood by the cupping-bowl, Anon. in Rh. 170.8.
ray, beam, prob. cj. for ὁλκὸν in Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 35.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: a drawing on or towards a thing, παιδεία ἔσθʼ ἡ παίδων ὁ. καὶ ἀγωγὴ πρὸς τὸν λόγον Pl. Lg. 659d.

data.quote: παιδεία ἔσθʼ ἡ παίδων ὁ. καὶ ἀγωγὴ πρὸς τὸν λόγον

children.definition: attraction, force of attraction, Id. Ti. 80c ; of a magnet, Epicur. Fr. 293 (pl.), Ph. 1.34 ; ἡ ὁ. τῆς ὁμοιότητος the attractive force of similarity, Pl. Cra. 435c.
tendency, διανοίας πρὸς τὸ ὄν Ph. 1.332.

children.label: III
children.definition: drawing down of the scale, weight, ὁ. ταλάντου χρυσίου Men. 383, cf. Arist. Mir. 833b10, Thphr. HP 9.16.8, Plb. 30.25.16, LXX 1 Es. 8.62(64), IG 2(2).659.27, 11(2).128.25 ( Delos, iii B. C.), etc. ; ὁλκὴν ἄγειν weigh so much, Michel 836.30 ( Milet.), etc.
the drachma, as a weight, Dsc. 1.30, S.E. P. 1.81, Hero *Geom. 23.55, Gal. 19.752, Asclep. ap. eund. 13.160, Ruf. Ren.Ves. 1.11.
drawing the scale, weighty, Nic. Th. 651, 908.
capable of being drawn out, ductile, sticky, Hp. Art. 36 ; μέλι Dsc. 2.82 ; ἔλαιον Plu. QConv. 2.696c ; of a plaster, Gal. 13.345.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., drawing well, of a cupping instrument, Paul.Aeg. 6.41 ( Comp.).

children.label: III
children.definition: ‘dragging’, Archig. ap. Gal. 8.87,111.

drawing to oneself, attractive, θερμόν τε καὶ ὁ. Arist. Pr. 931a25 ; μάθημα ψυχῆς ὁλκὸν ἀπὸ τοῦ γιγνομένου ἐπὶ τὸ ὄν Pl. R. 521d ; ὁλκὸν . . ψυχῆς πρὸς ἀλήθειαν ib. 527b ; ὁλκοτέρας τὰς ῥίζας ποιεῖν Thphr. CP 3.17.3 ( ἑλκοτέρας cod. A: ἑλκτικωτέρας Wimmer).

data.quote: μάθημα ψυχῆς ὁλκὸν ἀπὸ τοῦ γιγνομένου ἐπὶ τὸ ὄν

children.label: II
children.definition: trailing, ὁλκὰ βαίνων Hld. 10.30. Adv. Comp. -ότερον slowly, Id. 3.5.

children.label: III
children.definition: possible, ὁλκά· δυνατά, Hsch.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Pass., liable to be attracted, having a propensity, ὁ. διάνοιαι παρθένων πρὸς ἀρετήν Ph. 2.229.

children.label: I
children.definition: machine for hauling ships on land, hauling-engine, prob. a fixed capstan, windlass, Hdt. 2.154, 159, E. Rh. 146, 673 ; but also of movable engines of like kind, for hauling ships across the Isthmus of Corinth, Th. 3.15.
strap, rein (cf. ῥυτήρ), τμητοῖς ὁλκοῖς S. El. 863 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: furrow, track, trace, αἵματι δʼ ὁλκοὶ . . πλήθοντο A.R. 3.1391 ; σμίλης ὁλκός the traces of a chisel in the wood, Ar. Th. 779 (lyr.) ; ὁ. τοῦ ξύλου the furrow made by the wood, X. Cyn. 9.18 ; path, track, or orbit of a star or meteor, A.R. 3.141, 4.296, Nonn. D. 24.90 ; ἁμάξης ib. 1.96 ; ditch or channel, A.R. 1.375 ; οἴδματος ὁλκοί the waves, ib. 1167 ; ὁλκοὶ καλλιρόων ὑδάτων Milet. 1(9).343 ; body-coils of a serpent, Nic. Th. 266, al., Luc. Herm. 79 ; but, coiling movement of a serpent, Nic. Th. 162, al. ; cf. ὁ. γλώσσης Id. Al. 79, 281 ; of hair, coil, ὁλκὸς ἐθείρης, πλοκάμων . . ὁλκοί, Nonn. D. 3.413, 32.168 : generally, of anything drawn, αἵματος ὁλκῷ ib. 4.329, al. ; draught of wine, Antiph. 237.4 (pl.).
δάφνης ὁλκοί drawings, i. e. laurelboughs (or brooms made of them) drawn along, E. Ion 145 (lyr.) ; τερπνὸς ἀκούεται ὁ. ἁμάξης a chariot drawn, D.P. 191.
aqueduct, Cod.Just. 1.4.26 ; ὁ. ὑδάτων Lyd. Mens. 3.23.

children.label: III
children.definition: spider, Dsc. 2.63.

children.label: IV
children.definition: grass, mouse-barley, Plin. HN 27.90.
wooden drinking-bowl, Pamphil. ap. Ath. 11.494f.

definition: ὄλλυμι, S. Ant. 673, E. Or. 1303 ; part. ὀλλύς Il. 8.472, fem. pl. ὀλλῦσαι ib. 449 :—also ὀλλύω, Archil. 27, Com.Adesp. 608, ( προσαπ-) Hdt. 1.207 : poet. ὀλέκω (q. v.): impf. 3 pl. ὤλλυσαν A. Pers. 461, S. OC 394 ; Ep. ὀλέεσκον Q.S. 2.414 (cf. ὀλέκω) : fut. ὀλέσω Od. 13.399, Hes. Op. 180 ; Ep. also ὀλέσσω Il. 12.250, Od. 2.49 ; Ion. ὀλέω ( ἀπ-) Hdt. 1.34, etc. ; Att. ὀλῶ, εῖς, εῖ, S. OT 448, E. Andr. 856 (lyr.) : aor. ὤλεσα Il. 22.107, A. Ag. 1017 (lyr.), etc. ; Ep. ὄλεσα, ὄλεσσα, Od. 23.319, 21.284, etc. :— Med. ὄλλυμαι, Il. 20.21, S. OT 179 (lyr.) : impf. ὠλλύμην Id. El. 927, E. Alc. 633 : fut. ὀλέομαι, -οῦμαι, 2 pl. ὀλέεσθε Il. 21.133 ; but 3 sg. ὀλεῖται 2.325 : aor. 2 ὠλόμην, 3 sg. ὤλετο 13.772, A. Eu. 565 (lyr.), etc. ; Ion. ὀλέσκετο ( ἀπ- Od. 11.586) ; part. ὀλόμενος as Adj., v. οὐλόμενος: pf. ὄλωλα, v. B. III : plpf. ὀλώλειν Il. 10.187 :— Pass., aor. ὀλεσθῆναι, fut. ὀλεσθήσομαι ( ἀπ-), LXX Ps. 82(83).17, Gal. 9.728.—The simple Verb only Poet. and later Prose, as LXX, ἀπόλλυμι being used in Com. and Classical Prose.

children.label: A
children.definition: Act.:

children.label: I
children.definition: destroy, make an end of, and of living beings, kill, νῆάς τʼ ὀλέσας καὶ πάντας Ἀχαιούς Il. 8.498, cf. Od. 23.319 ; γένος ὀλέσσαι . . θανάτῳ Pi. P. 3.41 ; ρένος ὠλέσατε πρυμνόθεν A. Th. 1061 (anap.) ; θανεῖται καὶ θανοῦσʼ ὀλεῖ τινα S. Ant. 751 ; ὀλεῖ ὀλεῖ με E. Andr. 856 (lyr.) ; ἁ φιλοχρηματία Σπάρταν ὀλεῖ, ἄλλο γὰρ οὐδέν Orac. ap. Arist. Fr. 544 ; also, of doing away with evil, νῆστιν ὤλεσεν νόσον A. Ag. 1017 (lyr.).

data.quote: νῆάς τʼ ὀλέσας καὶ πάντας Ἀχαιούς

children.label: II
children.definition: lose, μένος, θυμόν, ψυχήν, ἦτορ ὀλέσαι, lose life, die, Il. 8.358, 13.763, 5.250 ; πόνον ὀρταλίχων ὀλέσαντες A. Ag. 54 (anap.) ; ἄγραν ὤλεσα Id. Eu. 148 (lyr.) ; τᾶς ἀνάνδρου κοίτας ὀλέσασα λέκτρον E. Med. 436 (lyr.).

children.label: B
children.definition: Med.,

children.label: I
children.definition: perish, come to an end, and of living beings, die, esp. a violent death, ἀπʼ αἰῶνος νέος ὤλεο Il. 24.725 ; ὤλεθʼ ὑπʼ Αἰγίσθοιο δόλῳ Od. 3.235 ; δόλοις ὀλούμεθʼ A. Ch. 888 ; ἦέ τις ὤλετʼ ὀλέθρῳ Od. 4.489 : c. acc. cogn., κακὸν οἶτον ὄληαι, ὀλέεσθε κακὸν μόρον, Il. 3.417, 21.133 ; θάνατον AP 7.745 (Antip. Sid.) ; ὄλοιο, ὄλοισθε, mayʼst thou, may ye perish ! a form of cursing very common in Trag., S. Ph. 961, 1019, 1285, etc. ; so ὀλοίμην Id. OT 645 ; ὄλοιτο ib. 1349 (lyr.), etc. ; ὄλοιντο Id. Tr. 383 :— Hom. has Act. and Med. in emphatic contrast, ὀλλύντων τε καὶ ὀλλυμένων Il. 4.451, 8.65, cf. 11.83.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be lost, μή τί μοι ἐκ μεγάρων κειμήλιον . . ὄληται Od. 15.91 ; ὤλετό μοι νόστος Il. 9.413, cf. Od. 1.168 ; κλέος Il. 9.415, cf. A. Supp. 918.

data.quote: μή τί μοι ἐκ μεγάρων κειμήλιον . . ὄληται

children.label: III
children.definition: pf. ὄλωλα (Syrac. ὀλώλω, Hilgard Exc. ex Hdn. p.30), to have perished, to be dead, undone, ruined, ὄλωλε μάχῃ ἔνι Il. 15.111, al., cf. A. Pers. 255, 1016 (lyr.), etc. ; τῶν ὀλωλότων of the dead, Id. Ag. 346, cf. 672, 1367, S. Ant. 174 : also of things, to be in a state of ruin, ἐσθίεταί μοι οἶκος, ὄλωλε δὲ πίονα ἔργα Od. 4.318.

data.quote: ἐσθίεταί μοι οἶκος, ὄλωλε δὲ πίονα ἔργα

children.definition: mortar, Sch. Ar. V. 238.

definition: ὁλμίον, τό, Dim. of ὅλμος, BGU 1666.12 (i A. D.).

children.definition: shaped like a ὁλμίσκος, Orib. 49.22.19.
Dim. of ὅλμος II, socket of the hinge of a door, S.E. M. 10.54, PLond. 3.1177.232 (ii A. D.).
tooth-socket, Ruf. Onom. 55 ; the hollows of the molar teeth, Poll. 2.93 (pl.).
frustum of a cone, POxy. 470r.35.
in socket or mortar-shape, Dsc. 4.170 ap. Orib. ( θολοειδῶς codd. Dsc.).
bray in a mortar, Heras ap. Gal. 13.1043, al., Philum. ap. Orib. 45.29.70, Alex.Trall. 12, Aët. 4.30.
one who brays in a mortar, Anon. in Gal. περὶ τῶν καθʼ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων (Helmreich Handschriftliche Studien zu Galen, Ansbach 1910).
maker of mortars, Arist. Pol. 1275b28.

definition: ὅλμος ( ὄλμος codd. of Hes. and Hdt., v. infr. II.1), ὁ,

children.definition: a round smooth stone ( περιφερὴς λίθος μάρμαρος, Hsch.), χεῖρας ἀπὸ ξίφεϊ τμήξας ἀπό τʼ αὐχένα κόψας, ὅλμον δʼ ὣς ἔσσενε κυλίνδεσθαι διʼ ὁμίλου Il. 11.147 (from which passage it was taken to signify the human trunk, Poll. 2.162, EM 460.17).

data.quote: χεῖρας ἀπὸ ξίφεϊ τμήξας ἀπό τʼ αὐχένα κόψας, ὅλμον δʼ ὣς ἔσσενε κυλίνδεσθαι διʼ ὁμίλου

children.label: II
children.definition: cylindrical or bowl-shaped body :
mortar, Hes. Op. 423, Hdt. 1.200, IG 2(2).1126.24, 12(5).872.82 ( Tenos, iii B. C.), PLille 9.9 (iii B. C.), etc.
kneading-trough, Ar. V. 201, 238.

hollow seat on which the Pythia prophesied, hence prov., ἐν ὅλμῳ κοιμᾶσθαι Plu. Prov. 2.14 ; ἐν ὅ. εὐνάσω Zen. 3.63 ; τοῦ τοίχου τὸ μέρος τοῦ κατὰ τὸν ὅλμον (in the temple of Amphiaraus at Rhamnus), Ἐφ.Ἀρχ. 1909.271.

children.label: b
children.definition: support, καθίσας τὸν ἄνθρωπον ὀκλὰξ ἐπὶ ὅλμων δύο Hp. Haem. 4.

data.quote: καθίσας τὸν ἄνθρωπον ὀκλὰξ ἐπὶ ὅλμων δύο

children.definition: drinking-vessel, Menesth. 1.
mouthpiece of a flute, Eup. 267, cf. Poll. 4.70, and v. ὑφόλμιον II.
dial, ὅλμου τοῦ λιθίνου ὃς ἐκαλεῖτο Ἑλληνιστὶ [γν]ώμων PHib. 1.27.26 (iii B. C.).

data.quote: ὅλμου τοῦ λιθίνου ὃς ἐκαλεῖτο Ἑλληνιστὶ [γν]ώμων

children.definition: stone used as a weight, prov. ὅ. ὑπὲρ κεφαλῆς Lib. Ep. 473.3.
all of silver, Ph. 1.666.
genuine purple dye, Procop. Arc. 25 : as Adj., holovera vestimenta, dyed purple through and through, Cod.Just. 11.9.4.
consisting only of short syllables, πυρρίχιος Anecd.Stud. 1.224.
with all its letters, written at full length, title of work by Menecrates, Gal. 13.503. Adv. -τως Id. 14.44.
write at full length, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.288e.
will written entirely in the handwriting of the testator, Gloss.
written in full, in Adv. -φως Sch. E. Andr. 575.

children.label: II
children.definition: written entirely in the same hand, PSI 3.223.6 (vi A. D.), PGrenf. 2.89.6 (vi A. D.).
entirely round, all round, in Adv. -ρως, μετρεῖσθαι Hero *Geom. 4.13.
wholly dactylic, Eust. 836.17.
S. Tr. 521 (lyr.).
ruinous, destructive, Man. 6.722.

definition: ὀλοεργός, όν, = foreg., Nic. Th. 828, Doroth. ap. Heph.Astr. 3.20.

children.definition: working the whole day, BGU 14iii 2, al. (iii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: lasting the whole day, in Adv. -ρως Tz.ad Hes. Op. 566.
holothurium, a kind of zoöphyte, Arist. HA 487b15, PA 681a17, Plin. HN 9.154.

destroy, v.l. for ὀλεθρεύω in LXX Ex. 12.23, al., Ph. 1.73 (citing Ex. l.c.), Ep.Hebr. 11.28 ; cf. ἐξολοθρεύω:—hence ὀλοθρ-ευτής, οῦ, ὁ, destroyer, 1 Ep.Cor. 10.10 :—fem. ὀλοθρ-εύτρια, gloss on λοιγίστρια, Hsch. :
destructive, Sch. Od. 11.128.

definition: ὀλοιός, όν, poet. for ὀλοός (q. v.). ὄλοισος· ὁ ἀπολλύς, Hsch.

children.definition: large stone, boulder, Ἕκτωρ ἀντικρὺ μεμαώς, ὀλοοίτροχος ὣς ἀπὸ πέτρης, ὅν τε κατὰ στεφάνης ποταμὸς χειμάρροος ὤσῃ ῥήξας . . ἔχματα πετρης Il. 13.137 ; = τὸ κυλινδρικὸν σχῆμα, Democr. 162 ; of the rounded muscles of an athleteʼs arm, ἕστασαν ἠΰτε πέτροι ὀλοίτροχοι, οὕστε κυλίνδων χειμάρρους ποταμὸς μεγάλαις περιέξεσε δίναις Theoc. 22.49 ; rolled down by besieged people upon their assailants, Hdt. 8.52, Orac. ap. eund. 5.92.βʹ, X. An. 4.2.3, Zos. 1.52. (The ancients derived it from ὀλοός ‘destructive’ or from ὅλος, and disagreed as to the breathing and accent, Sch.Il. l.c.)

data.quote: Ἕκτωρ ἀντικρὺ μεμαώς, ὀλοοίτροχος ὣς ἀπὸ πέτρης, ὅν τε κατὰ στεφάνης ποταμὸς χειμάρροος ὤσῃ ῥήξας . . ἔχματα πετρης
ἕστασαν ἠΰτε πέτροι ὀλοίτροχοι, οὕστε κυλίνδων χειμάρρους ποταμὸς μεγάλαις περιέξεσε δίναις

children.definition: completely pure, Steph. in Hp. 1.183 D.
stake made of a single reed, BGU 1529.10 (iii B. C.).
entirely beautiful, Sammelb. 343, 1990,6124, BCH 27.331.
to be offered as a whole burnt-offering, LXX Si. 45.14, 4 Ma. 18.11.
brought as a whole offering, θυσία Ph. 1.668.
whole burnt-offering, LXX Le. 5.10, al.
presentation of such an offering, LXX Ge. 8.20, al.
Mon.Ant. 23.154 No. 112 ( Adanda), cf. PMag.Par. 1.2396, PMag.Leid.V. 1.35.
IPE 2.342 ( Phanagoria).
Ph. 1.468, PMag.Par. 1.3148, Gloss.

bring a burnt-offering, offer whole, X. An. 7.8.4 : impf. ὡλοκαύτει ib. 5 :— Pass., ὁλοκαυτεῖται (v.l. -οῦται) J. AJ 3.9.1:—more usu. ὁλοκαυτ-όω, ὡλοκαύτωσαν v.l. in X. Cyr. 8.3.24 ; ὁλοκαυτῶσαι J. AJ 1.13.1, etc. ( ὁλοκαυτοῦσιν Plu. QConv. 2.694b, ὁλοκαυτῶν J. AJ 3.9.1, may belong to either form).
Porph. Abst. 2.54 :— Subst. ὁλοκαυτ-ισμός, ὁ, = ὁλοκαύτησις, Phot.
burnt whole, Call. Fr. 1.49 P. ; τὸ ὁ. LXX Le. 6.23(16) ; ὁ. θυσία Ph. 1.668, al.
in full flame, opp. ἡμίκαυτος, Gal. 18(1).225.
burnt-offering, LXX Ex. 10.25, al., J. AJ 10.4.5.
sacrifice of a burnt-offering, LXX Ex. 29.25, al., J. AJ 3.9.1 : but ὁλοκαύτ-ησις, εως, ἡ, IG 42(1).97.2, al. (Epid.) ; cf. ὁλοκαυστέω, ὁλοκαυστησις.
to be in good health, POxy. 1158.3 (iii A.D.), PMag.Par. 1.136, etc.

completeness or soundness in all parts, τοῦ σώματος, τῶν αἰσθητηρίων, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.33, Plu. Stoic.rep. 2.1041f : abs., Act.Ap. 3.16, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1063f, Demetr. Eloc. 3, SIG 1142 ( Phrygia, i/ii A. D.), POxy. 123.6 (iii/iv A. D.).

complete, entire, perfect, opp. κολοβός, Arist. HA 585b36 ; uncastrated, κίχλαι Pl.Com. 174.9 ; τοὺς ἱερέας ὁ. νόμος εἶναι Anaxandr. 39.10, cf. Men. 233, Luc. Asin. 33 ; ὁ. ὑγιής τε Pl. Ti. 44c ; σῶμα Diog.Oen. 39 ; ὁ. μὲν . . ὄντες καὶ ἀπαθεῖς κακῶν . . , ὁ. δὲ . . καὶ εὐδαίμονα φάσματα μυούμενοι perfect, complete, Pl. Phdr. 250c ; ὁ. καὶ γνήσιον Id. Lg. 759c ; ἐν ὁ. δέρματι Luc. Philops. 8 ; also of evils, ὁ. πήρωσις Democr. 296 ; [ἡ ἀνελευθερία] οὐ πᾶσιν ὁ. παραγίνεται Arist. EN 1121b19, cf. 1126a12 ; simply, whole, complete, ἔτεσιν δυσὶν οὐχ ὁλοκλήρ[οι]ς IG 14.1386 ; ὁ. βουλευτήριον BGU 1027.12 (iv A. D.) ; ὁ. οἰκία PLond. 3.930.13, etc. ; ὁ. κολλούρια drug-pencils used as wholes, for insertion in cavities, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.23.1. Adv. -ρως Erot. s.v. ἀπαρτί, S.E. P. 3.226, Gal. 16.68, Hld. 7.8.

data.quote: ὁ. μὲν . . ὄντες καὶ ἀπαθεῖς κακῶν . . , ὁ. δὲ . . καὶ εὐδαίμονα φάσματα μυούμενοι

children.definition: complete recovery, Serapio in Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.101.5.
with the whole shin, σκελὶς ὁ. a ham containing the whole leg, Pherecr. 108.13.
coarsely pounded, Dsc. 5.55.
full-orbed, σελήνη Mich. in PN 82.17.
χαμαίπιτυς, Dsc. 3.158, Apollod. ap. Ath. 15.681d ( ὁλόκληρος is f.l. in Paul.Aeg. 5.46, ὁλόπυρος in Orib. 12 s.v. χαμαίπιτυς).
earth-almond, Cyperus esculentus, Hp. Mul. 1.78, cf. Gal. 19.126 ; also ὀροκωνῖτις (q. v.).
shining all over, Ὄλυμπος Arist. Mu. 400a8.
all white, τάριχος Antiph. 186.3 ; χλαμύς Philetaer. 20 ; στρόφιον Plu. Arat. 53 ; ὄρνιθες Paus. 8.17.3 ; albino, Heph.Astr. 1.1.
of massive stone, βασίλειον Str. 17.1.42.
entirely of fine linen, σουδάριον PMag.Osl. 1.268.
Theopomp.Com. 61, Men. 112.
screeching, νυκτερίς IG 14.1934.

loud cry, esp. of women invoking a god, αἱ δʼ ὀλολυγῇ πᾶσαι Ἀθήνῃ χεῖρας ἀνέσχον Il. 6.301, cf. h.Ven. 19 (pl.), Ar. Lys. 240 ; δοκέει ἔμοιγε καὶ <ἡ> ὀ. ἐπὶ ἱροῖσι ἐνταῦθα πρῶτον γενέσθαι Hdt. 4.189 ; θεία μακάρων ὀ. Ar. Av. 222 ; κραυγῇ τε καὶ ὀ. χρωμένων, of the alarm given in the attack on Plataea, Th. 2.4.—Mostly in good sense, sts. even opp. to a wailing cry, ἀντίμολπον ἧκεν ὀλολυγῆς μέγαν κωκυτόν E. Med. 1176 ; σύν τʼ εὐαγορίᾳ σύν τʼ εὔγμασι σύν τʼ ὀλολυγαῖς Call. Lav.Pall. 139.

data.quote: αἱ δʼ ὀλολυγῇ πᾶσαι Ἀθήνῃ χεῖρας ἀνέσχον
δοκέει ἔμοιγε καὶ <ἡ> ὀ. ἐπὶ ἱροῖσι ἐνταῦθα πρῶτον γενέσθαι
σύν τʼ εὐαγορίᾳ σύν τʼ εὔγμασι σύν τʼ ὀλολυγαῖς

children.definition: loud cry, mostly of joy, E. Heracl. 782 (lyr.) ; Κυβέλης in honour of C., AP 6.173 ( Rhian.).

loud cry, mostly of joy, in honour of the gods, ὀ. ἱρὸν . . παιώνισον A. Th. 268 ; ὀ. εὐφημοῦντα τῇδε λαμπάδι ἐπορθιάζειν Id. Ag. 28, cf. 595, E. Or. 1137, LXX Ze. 1.10, PMag.Lond. 121.323 : pl., Epicur. Fr. 143, 419 ; song of triumph, ἐφυμνῆσαι . . ὀ. ἀνδρὸς θεινομένου A. Ch. 387 (lyr.) ; rarely of lamentation, AP 7.182 ( Mel.).
croaking of the male frog, Arist. HA 536a11, Ael. NA 9.13 ; note of water-creatures, ib. 6.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: Theoc. 7.139, Arat. 948, an unknown animal, evidently named from its note : some take it for a small owl, others for a singing bird, others again for the tree-frog ; cf. Eub. 104, Thphr. Sign. 42, AP 5.291.5 ( Agath.).

definition: ὀλολύζω, Od. 22.411, etc. : fut. -ύξομαι E. El. 691, later -ύξω LXX Is. 16.7, Am. 8.3 : aor. ὠλόλυξα, Ep. ὀ. (v. infr.) :—

children.definition: cry with a loud voice, in Hom. esp. of women crying aloud to the gods in prayer or thanksgiving, ὣς εἰποῦσʼ ὀλόλυξε· θεὰ δέ οἱ ἔκλυεν ἀρῆς Od. 4.767, cf. h.Ap. 445 ; αἱ δʼ ὀλόλυξαν, at a sacrifice, Od. 3.450 ; of a cry of exultation, ἴθυσέν ῥʼ ὀλολύξαι 22.408, cf. 411 ; also of the cries of goddesses, h.Ap. 119 ; so later, mostly of women crying to the gods, ὀλολύξατε νῦν ἐπὶ μολπαῖς A. Eu. 1043 (lyr.) ; ὠλόλυξεν ἐν μέσαις σταθεῖσα Βάκχαις E. Ba. 689 ; mostly in sign of joy (cf. ὀλολυγή), ἢν μὲν ἔλθῃ πύστις εὐτυχὴς σέθεν, ὀλολύξεται πᾶν δῶμα Id. El. 691, cf. Ar. Eq. 1327, Theoc. 17.64 ; μὴ φλαῦρον μηδὲν γρύζειν, ἀλλʼ ὀ. Ar. Pax 97 ; ἐπὶ τῷ μηδένα πώποτε τηλικοῦτʼ ὀλολύξαι σεμνυνόμενος D. 18.259 ; ὠλόλυξαν μὲν αἱ γυναῖκες, ἠλάλαξαν δὲ οἱ ἄνδρες Hld. 3.5 ; of nymphs crying aloud to Hecate, A.R. 3.1218.

data.quote: ὣς εἰποῦσʼ ὀλόλυξε· θεὰ δέ οἱ ἔκλυεν ἀρῆς
ἢν μὲν ἔλθῃ πύστις εὐτυχὴς σέθεν, ὀλολύξεται πᾶν δῶμα
μὴ φλαῦρον μηδὲν γρύζειν, ἀλλʼ ὀ.
ἐπὶ τῷ μηδένα πώποτε τηλικοῦτʼ ὀλολύξαι σεμνυνόμενος
ὠλόλυξαν μὲν αἱ γυναῖκες, ἠλάλαξαν δὲ οἱ ἄνδρες

children.definition: addicted to wailing, An.Ox. 4.336.
professional crier at sacrifices, SIG 982.25 ( Pergam., ii B. C.).
effeminate, dissolute person ( ὁ γυναικώδης καὶ κατάθεος καὶ βάκηλος Phot.), Anaxandr. 34.4, Men. 34. (On the accent, v. Hdn. Gr. 2.938.)

data.quote: ὁ γυναικώδης καὶ κατάθεος καὶ βάκηλος

children.definition: completely bald, Cyran. 77.
whole, entire, Hero *Stereom. 1.59.
black all over, αἴλουρος PMag.Leid.V. 4.2 ; κριός PMag.Lond. 121.539.
six, Anatolius ap. Theol.Ar. 36 : Ion. οὐλομέλεια (q.v.).
to be sound, entire, ζῷα (embryos) -οῦντα Gal. 19.177.
whole of limb, not dismembered, πλεκτάς Diph. 34.2 ; κρέα Posidon. 9 J., IG 12(7).515.49 ( Amorgos) ; ὁλομελῆ alone, Str. 15.3.19 ; ὁ. κρόκος uniform, Dsc. 1.26.
in entire parts, in large or whole pieces, κρέα D.S. 5.28, Dsc. 5.75. Adv. -ρῶς Arist. ap. D.L. 5.28.
solid, without marrow, of bones, Pall. in Hp. 12.286 C.
all over dung, γνάθος Com.Adesp. ap. Eust. 1329.30.
edible fruit of the wild fig, Hes. Fr. 160.1, Thphr. CP 5.1.8, Anon. ( ὁ φιλόσοφος) ap. Ath. 3.77f, LXX Ca. 2.13 ; ὄ. χειμερινοί Hp. Nat.Mul. 33, al.
sterile summer fruit of the cultivated fig, Gal. 12.133.
sterile male inflorescence of the caprifig, breeding ψῆνες, which fertilize σῦκα, Hdt. 1.193.
bear ὄλονθοι, Thphr. HP 3.7.3.

bearing ὄλονθοι, Thphr. CP 5.1.8, Anon. (ὁ φιλόσοφος) ap. Ath. 3.77f, PCair.Zen. 33.12 (iii B. C.). (In this group ὀλονθ- is found in good codd. of Hdt. 1.193, Hp. Nat.Mul. 10, 17, 33, Mul. 1.78, 2.112, 113, 117, Ath. l.c., corroborated by PCair.Zen. l.c. ; ὀλυνθ- elsewhere, as also in ὀλυνθάζω, ὀλύνθη, ὀλυνθηφόρος.)
the whole night through : neut. -ιον as Adv., Sch. Lyc. 815 (p.261 S.).
wholly dry, Sm. Ps. 57(58).10.

definition: ὀλοοίτροπα παρὰ Ῥοδίοις ἑπτὰ πλάσματα εἰς θυσίαν, Hsch. ὀλοοίτροχος, v. ὀλοίτροχος.

children.definition: to be constituted a whole, Dam. Pr. 276, cf. EM 821.37.

destructive, deadly, ὀλοὴ Κήρ Il. 18.535 ; μοῖρʼ ὀλοή 16.849, al. ; ὀλοῷ Ἀχιλῆι 24.39 ; πυρὸς ὀλοοῖο Od. 12.68 ; ὀλοῷ ἐνὶ δεσμῷ 22.200 ; πόλεμος, μάχης πόνος, Il. 3.133, 16.568 ; λύσσα, γόος, μῆνις, 9.305, 23.10, Od. 3.135 ; γήραος οὐδός Il. 24.487 ; νύξ 16.567, al. ; ὀ. τύχαι A. Pr. 553 (lyr.) ; νιφάς Id. Th. 213 (lyr.) ; θηρὸς κέρας Call. Fr. 249 ; γηγενέων ἀνδρῶν ὀ. στάχυς A.R. 3.1338 : c. inf., ὀ. φέρειν ζυγόν, of the wild horse, Opp. C. 3.261 ; ὀλοὰ φρονεῖν design ill, τινι Il. 16.701 : Comp. ὀλοώτερος 3.365, 23.439 : Sup. -ώτατος (as fem.), ὀδμή Od. 4.442 : neut. pl. as Adv., ὀλοὰ στένει S. Tr. 846 (lyr.), cf. El. 843 (lyr.).—Rarer collat. forms are ὀλοιός, as ὀλοιὴ μοῖρα πέδησεν Il. 22.5 ; ὀλοιῇσι φρεσὶ θύει 1.342 ; γῆρας ὀλοιόν h.Ven. 224 ; ὀλώϊος, Hes. Th. 591 ; θάρσος ὀλώϊον Nonn. D. 13.416 ; οὐλοός, A.R. 2.85, 3.1402 (fem. -ός Man. 6.464) ; ὀλός (q.v.).

children.label: II
children.definition: destroyed, lost, ὀλοοὺς ἀπέλειπον A. Pers. 962 (lyr.).

definition: ὀλοόφρων, ονος, ὁ, ἡ, ( ὀλοός, φρήν)

children.definition: meaning mischief, baleful (so always in Il.), ὕδρος 2.723 ; λέων 15.630 ; σῦς κάπρος 17.21 ; but

children.label: II
children.definition: Od., crafty, sagacious, of persons, Ἄτλας 1.52 ; Αἰήτης 10.137 ; Μίνως 11.322. (Sense II is derived from sense I, cf. the signf. of δαΐφρων and δεινός ; expld. by Cleanth.Stoic. 1.125 by ὁ ὑπὲρ ὅλων φρονῶν, i. e. ὁλο-.)
a complete πάππος (a pun on the name Φιλόπαππος), dub. in MAMA 1.267 (nr. Laodicea Combusta).
make into a whole, Simp. in Ph. 636.38, Dam. Pr. 159.
creating the whole, Ζεύς Dam. Pr. 245.
all purple, X. Cyr. 8.3.13, LXX Nu. 4.7, Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.180e.
all green, Cyran. 278.
with whole ( i.e. undivided) wings, a generic name of insects such as bees, wasps, etc., opp. σχιζόπτερα, Arist. APo. 96b39, cf. PA 692b13, IA 709b30, 713a4.
pluck out, tear out, [χαίτην] ὤλοψας βίῃφι Call. Dian. 77 ; ἑὰν ὠλόψατο χαίταν AP 7.241 (Antip. Sid.) ; ὤλοψεν . . βότρυν ἐθείρης cj. in Nonn. D. 40.104.

children.label: II
children.definition: strip off, Nic. Th. 595.

definition: ὁλοπυρῖται ἄρτοι, = sq., Ostr. 1305 ( iA. D., written -εῖται).

children.definition: of unground wheat, esp. of wheat boiled whole, later word for πύανος, Heliod.Hist. 3.

definition: ὁλορριζί, Adv. of sq., LXX Es. 3.13.

children.definition: with the entire root, Thphr. HP 3.18.5 : metaph., ὁλόρριζοι ἀπώλοντο LXX Jb. 4.7.
the ink of the cuttle-fish, Hp. Epid. 4.20 (vulg.), Phryn. PS p.19B., Phot. ; prob. read by Gal. in Hp. Morb. 2.73.
blood, AP 15.25.1 ( Besant. Ara).
Hdn.Gr. 1.154 ; only found in voc. ὦ ὀλὲ δαῖμον Alcm. 55.

definition: ὅλος, η, ον, Ion. οὖλος, η, ον, as in Hom. (twice, v. infr.), Xenoph. (v. infr.), Parm. 8.4, Hp. Acut. 14, Carn. 13, al. (but ὅλος in Hdt. 2.126, 4.64, 7.167, 8.113 (cf. ἡμι-ολίας 5.88), Hp. Epid. 1.7, Herod. 3.18, 5.12, 6.7 (but οὖλος 8.56) ; ὅλως dub. in Thgn. 73 codd.) :—

children.definition: whole, entire, complete in all its parts, of persons and things, ἄρτος οὖλος a whole loaf, Od. 17.343 ; μηνὶ δʼ ἄρʼ οὔλῳ in a whole month, 24.118 ; οὖλος ὁρᾷ, οὖλος δὲ νοεῖ, οὖλος δέ τʼ ἀκούει (sc. ὁ θεός) Xenoph. 24 ; ὅλος ἑσπέρας ὀφθαλμός, i.e. the full moon, Pi. O. 3.19 ; ὁ ὅ. χρόνος ib. 2.30 ; τρεῖς ὅλους . . ἑκμήνους χρόνους S. OT 1136 ; ἐπʼ ὤμοις ὅλην πόλιν φέρων a whole city, E. Ph. 1131 ; ἐκπιεῖν ὅλον πίθον Id. Cyc. 217 ; ὅλους ἐκ κριβάνου βοῦς Ar. Ach. 85 ; λαβράκιον ὀπτᾶν ὅ. Antiph. 222.3, etc. ; πόλεις ὅλαι whole, entire cities, Pl. Grg. 512b ; ὅλη ἡ πόλις, the city as a whole, Id. R. 519e ; ὅλους ποιητὰς ἐκμανθάνειν learn whole poets by heart, Id. Lg. 811a : it may either precede the Art. or follow the Subst., τῆς ἡμέρας ὅλης in the course of the whole day, X. An. 3.3.11 ; διʼ ὅλης τῆς νυκτός ib. 4.2.4 ; ὅλην τὴν νύκτα or τὴν νύκτα ὅλην, Id. Cyr. 7.5.15, Men. 67.2, Pl. Smp. 219c ; ὅ. τὸ δέρμα Men. 498 ; ἡ πόλις ὅ. Id. 882, etc. : less freq. between Art. and Subst., τὸν ὅ. ἀμφὶ χρόνον Pi. O. 2.30 ; ἡ ὅ. ἀδικία Pl. R. 344c ; τὸ ὅ. πρόσωπον Id. Prt. 329e ; τῇ ὅ. φάλαγγι X. An. 4.8.11 : joined with εἷς, ἡμέρας . . οὐχ ὅλης μιᾶς S. Ph. 480 ; εἶδος ἓν ὅλον Pl. Ti. 56e ; with πᾶς, ὅλην καὶ πᾶσαν τὴν οἰκίαν Id. Lg. 808a, cf. R. 486a ; πρὸς τῷ διακινδυνεύειν ὅ. καὶ πᾶς ἦν Plb. 3.94.10 (so without πᾶς, οὕτως ἔκφρων ἦν καὶ ὅλος πρὸς τῷ λήμματι καὶ τῷ δωροδοκήματι, ὥστε . . D. 19.127) ; τὸ ὅ. αὐτοῖς ἦν καὶ τὸ πᾶν Ἀπελλῆς Plb. 5.26.5.

data.quote: πᾶς, ὅλην καὶ πᾶσαν τὴν οἰκίαν
πρὸς τῷ διακινδυνεύειν ὅ. καὶ πᾶς ἦν
πᾶς, οὕτως ἔκφρων ἦν καὶ ὅλος πρὸς τῷ λήμματι καὶ τῷ δωροδοκήματι, ὥστε . .
τὸ ὅ. αὐτοῖς ἦν καὶ τὸ πᾶν Ἀπελλῆς

children.definition: whole, i.e. safe and sound, ὑγιὴς καὶ ὅ. Lys. 6.12, cf. Pl. Men. 77a.
entire, utter, ὅ. ἁμάρτημα an utter blunder, X. HG 5.3.7 ; πλάσμα ὅ. ἐστὶν ἡ διαθήκη utter fiction, D. 45.29.

Adv., ὅλον or τὸ ὅ. wholly, entirely, διαφέρει ὅ. τε καὶ πᾶν Pl. Alc. 1.109b ; διαφέρει ὅ. καὶ τὸ πᾶν Id. Lg. 944c ; ὅλῳ καὶ παντί Id. Phd. 79e ; τῷ ὅ. καὶ παντὶ διοίσει Id. R. 527c ; τῷ παντὶ καὶ ὅ. Id. Lg. 734e ; εἰς τὸ ὅ. Id. Plt. 302b : with a Prep., κατὰ ὅλον on the whole, generally, opp. ἀπολαβὼν μέρος τι, Id. R. 392d ; so κατὰ ὅλου Id. Men. 77a ; διʼ ὅλου, καθʼ ὅλου (v. διόλου, καθόλου) ; αἱ κράσεις διʼ ὅλων Plu. Comm.not. 2.1078c, cf. 1078d : in this signf. also without a Prep., τὸ μὲν ὅ. generally speaking, Pl. Phdr. 261a, D. 44.11 ; τὸ δʼ ὅ. and in general, in short, PTeb. 33.16 (ii B. C.) ; οὐδὲ Φιλόξενον ὅλʼ ἐξ ὅλων εὗρον I have entirely failed to find P., POxy. 936.20 (iii A. D.).

all, ὅλων στρατηγός S. Aj. 1105, cf. Men. Pk. 225, Nonn. D. 47.482, AP 5.216 ( Paul.Sil.), 7.679 ( Sophronius) ; ὅλη πόλις every city, LXX 1 Ki. 14.23 ; πρὸ τῶν ὅ. τὸ προσκύνημά σου ποιῶ before all things, PTeb. 418.4 (iii A. D.) ; ἀσπάζομαι . . πάντας τοὺς ἐν τῇ οἰκίᾳ ὅ. κατʼ ὄνομα PLond. 2.404.15 (iv A. D.), cf. PIand. 13.20 (iv A. D.).

data.quote: ἀσπάζομαι . . πάντας τοὺς ἐν τῇ οἰκίᾳ ὅ. κατʼ ὄνομα

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., τὸ ὅ. the universe, Pl. Grg. 508a, Ly. 214b, etc. ; differing from τὸ πᾶν, as implying a definite order, Arist. Metaph. 1024a3, cf. Pl. Tht. 204a sq. (but as not including void, Placit. 2.1.7) ; also ἡ τῶν ὅ. τάξις X. Cyr. 8.7.22.

τὰ ὅ. oneʼs all, τὰ ὅ. πεπρακέναι D. 18.28 ; τοῖς ὅ. ἡττᾶσθαι lose oneʼs all, be utterly ruined, Id. 9.64 ; in full, τοῖς ὅ. πράγμασιν ἐσφαλμένος Plb. 18.33.1, etc. ; τοῖς ὅ., = ὅλως, altogether, Philipp. ap. D. 18.39 : with neg., not at all, Phld. Rh. 2.135S., Aristid. 2.274,304J. ; τοῖς ὅ. ἠφάνισαν utterly destroyed it, PRyl. 152.14 (i A. D.), cf. Aristid. 2.262J. ; κινδυνεύει τῷ ὅ. ἐξαρθῆναι there is a risk of its being entirely carried away, PRyl. 133.19 (i A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. ὅλως ( Dor. οὔλως Pempel. ap. Stob. 4.25.52) wholly, altogether, ὅ. σοφόν Pl. R. 568a ; ἀλγοῦνθʼ ὅ. Id. Phlb. 36a ; ὅ. ψεύδεται he speaks utter falsehood, Isoc. 15.31, etc.

on the whole, speaking generally, in short, ὅ. δʼ οὐδεὶς ἔστιν ὅντινʼ οὐ πεφενάκικʼ ἐκεῖνος D. 2.7, cf. 14, al. ; διψῆν καὶ πεινῆν καὶ ὅ. τὰς ἐπιθυμίας Pl. R. 437b, cf. Cra. 406a ; τί οὖν κωλύει πάντα ἀφῃρῆσθαι καὶ ὅ. τὴν πολιτείαν ; D. 20.3 ; ὅ. εἰπεῖν Arist. Ph. 202b19, etc.

data.quote: ὅ. δʼ οὐδεὶς ἔστιν ὅντινʼ οὐ πεφενάκικʼ ἐκεῖνος
διψῆν καὶ πεινῆν καὶ ὅ. τὰς ἐπιθυμίας

children.definition: Thgn. 73, s. v. l.), οὐχ ὅ. or ὅ. οὐ not at all, ὅ. μὴ διαλέγεσθαι X. Mem. 1.2.35 ; ὅ. οὔτʼ ἀφελὼν οὔτε προσθείς D. 3.35 ; οὔτʼ ἐλεῶν οὔθʼ ὅ. ἄνθρωπον ἡγούμενος Id. 21.101, cf. 46 ; οὐδὲ εἷς ὅ. Men. 65.9 ; μὴ ὄντος ὅ. τοῦ Σωκράτους Arist. Cat. 13b19 ; μηδὲ ὅ. εἶναι τοὺς θεούς Luc. Tim. 10.

data.quote: οὔτʼ ἐλεῶν οὔθʼ ὅ. ἄνθρωπον ἡγούμενος

children.definition: actually, really, καλῶς ποιήσεις ἐλθοῦσα . . πρὸς ἡμᾶς ἵνα ὅ. ἴδωμέν σε POxy. 1676.31 (iii A. D.) ; so perh. in 1 Ep.Cor. 5.1. ( ὅλ ( ϝ) ος from I.-E. * sólwos, cf. Skt. sárvas ‘whole’, and perh. Lat. salus, salvus.)

data.quote: καλῶς ποιήσεις ἐλθοῦσα . . πρὸς ἡμᾶς ἵνα ὅ. ἴδωμέν σε

definition: ὁλοσηρικοπράτης [ᾱ], ου, ὁ, in Lat. form

children.definition: holosericoprata, silk-mercer, Champollion-Figeac Chartes Latines 1 vi 14, al. (vi A. D.).
of silk, ῥάκος Cyran. 120 : -κόν, τό, silk, Hsch. s.v. Σῆρες, Edict.Diocl. 22.14, al. :—written ὁλο-σειρικός ib. 19.14 k, al.
all iron, μάχαιρα IG 2(2).1481 (iv B. C.), cf. Antiph. 216, IG ΙΙ(2).145.37 ( Delos, iv B. C.), Plu. Cam. 40 ; ὁλοσίδηροι, οἱ, soldiers wearing coats of mail, = Lat. clibanarii, Lyd. Mag. 1.46.
quite shady, Str. 6.1.9ap.Eust.ad D.P. 364 ( παλίνσκιος codd. Str.).
entirely eaten by worms,POsl. 26.14 (i B. C.).
entirely of emerald, BCH 32.248.
drunk all at one draught, ὁλοσπάδες S. Fr. 1076 ap. Phot. ( ὁλοσπαδεῖς Hsch.).
all of spondees, Eust. 836.16.
all-bone, Plantago Bellardi, Dsc. 4.11, Plin. HN 27.91.
consisting all of warp-threads, ταινία Poll. 7.32.
tempered all through, of an iron ring, PMag.Par. 1.2961 ; σίδηρος Cyran. 6.
entirely round, Sch. Opp. H. 2.370.
moving altogether, Hsch. s.v. ἐλελίστροφε.
quite defective, marg. gloss in cod. of AP 6.269.
Phot.
made of solid beaten metal, opp. cast, hollow, AP 11.174 ( Lucill.), cf. LXX Si. 50.9, Plin. HN 33.82, Hsch.s.vv. ὁλόσφυροι, ναστός : condemned by Phryn. 180.
= foreg., J. AJ 14.7.1 (v.l. -σφύρητος, v. foreg.).
piece of beaten metal, Ammon. Diff. p.41 V.
Herm. in Phdr. p.82A., cf. Hsch. ; interpol. in Phryn. 180, v.l. in Artem. 2.5.
with undivided ankles, Ar.Byz. Epit. 1.19.
general survey or estimate, Str. 2.1.24, Corn. ND 20 ; καθʼ ὁλοσχέρειαν in general terms, διαλέγεσθαι Phld. Rh. 1.251 S. ; κατὰ ὁλοσχέρειαν, opp. κατὰ μέρη, S.E. M. 10.53.
lumpiness, solidity, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.24.34.
